translation.en: I don't have anything before, I don't have anything behind.
translation.creole: Me no gat befo', me no got behin.'

translation.en: I don't have any biscuits in your barrel.
translation.creole: Me no gat no biscuit a-you' barrel

translation.en: I wasn't born in Ogle's back dam.
translation.creole: Me no bo'n a-Ogle back dam

translation.en: I'm telling the story as I heard it.
translation.creole: Me sell me 'tory as me buy am

translation.en: It's easier to stop a river than a woman's tongue.
translation.creole: Mo' easy fo' 'tap ribah dan woman tongue

translation.en: The longer you stay, the more your bread will burn.
translation.creole: Mo' langah you 'tan', mo' you bake-bake a-col.'

translation.en: The more men refuse, the more dinner is saved.
translation.creole: Mo' man refuse, mo' dinnah save

translation.en: More money, more sin.
translation.creole: Mo' money, mo' sin

translation.en: The more the monkey climbs, the more he shows his tail.
translation.creole: Mo' monkey climb, mo' he show he tail

translation.en: When money is gone, friends are gone.
translation.creole: Money done, frien' done

translation.en: Money doesn't grow on trees.
translation.creole: Money na a-grow 'pon tree

translation.en: Money doesn't make the man.
translation.creole: Money na mek man

translation.en: The monkey knows which tree it's climbing on.
translation.creole: Monkey know wha' tree he a-climb 'pon

translation.en: The monkey made his child, he made it so that it would spoil him.
translation.creole: Monkey mek he picknie, he mek ama teh 'e 'pile am

translation.en: Monkey says his child's eye will go deep deep.
translation.creole: Monkey men' 'e chil' eye teh 'e go deep deep

translation.en: If the father monkey jumps, the mother monkey jumps, the baby monkey must also jump.
translation.creole: Monkey papa jump, monkey mamma jump, monkey picknie mus' jump

translation.en: The monkey plays the fiddle for the baboon to run a race.
translation.creole: Monkey play fiddle fo' de baboon run race

translation.en: The monkey put his head in the salmon pot, he says the world goes round.
translation.creole: Monkey put he head a-salmon pat, he say de worl' go roun'

translation.en: The monkey says "What's in my belly is mine, what's in my mouth is what the jackman wants."
translation.creole: Monkey say "Wha' deh a-me belly a-me own, wha' deh a-me mout' a jackman want

translation.en: The monkey takes trouble from the bush and brings it home.
translation.creole: Monkey tek trouble a-bush bring am a-house

translation.en: When the monkey becomes rich, he roasts butter on a stick.
translation.creole: Monkey tu'n rich, he roas' buttah 'pon 'tick

translation.en: The moon and the star are neighbors.
translation.creole: Moon an' 'tar a-neighbour

translation.en: The moon is running, but the day will catch it.
translation.creole: Moon a-run, but day a-ketch am

translation.en: More rain, more rest
translation.creole: Mo' rain, mo' rest

translation.en: Mouth is a freeman, hand is a slave.
translation.creole: Mout' a freeman, han' a slabe

translation.en: The mouth makes it, somewhere else pays for it.
translation.creole: Mout' a-mek am, someweh else a-pay fo' am

translation.en: A mouth that cuts trousers can't fit the master.
translation.creole: Mout' cut trouses can't fit massa

translation.en: What the mouth consumes, the back suffers for.
translation.creole: Mout' eat, back pay

translation.en: I'm not the first one to tell Matty that his skin is black.
translation.creole: Na a fus' wan to tell matty he 'kin black

translation.en: Not everyone who goes to church, goes to pray.
translation.creole: Na all a-go a-chu'ch house, a-go fo' pray

translation.en: Not every dog that plays with you has your best interest at heart.
translation.creole: Na all daag wah play wid you gat you good a-he min'

translation.en: Not every horse that takes the lead initially wins the race.
translation.creole: Na all haas wah get fus' jump a-win race

translation.en: Not everyone who is courting gets married.
translation.creole: Na all man a-cou'tin' a-married

translation.en: Not every man who wears trousers is a man.
translation.creole: Na all man a-wear trouses a man

translation.en: Not all water that comes from the eye is tears.
translation.creole: Na all watah wah come out a-yeye a-cry

translation.en: Don't curse the snake before you go into the bush.
translation.creole: Na cuss snake befo' you walk a-bush

translation.en: Don't curse the water spirit when you go to the creek.
translation.creole: Na cuss watah mamma w'en you go a-creek

translation.en: Don't cast your eyes on me.
translation.creole: Na cut you' yeye 'pon me

translation.en: Don't cut your nose to spite your face.
translation.creole: Na cut you' nose fo' pile you' face

translation.en: It's the lack of a tongue that makes a cow unable to talk.
translation.creole: Na de lacking ob a tongue mek cow can't talk

translation.en: Don't dirty the water where you drink from.
translation.creole: Na dutty de pon' weh you dip you' watah

translation.en: Not every big head has sense.
translation.creole: Na ebery big head gat sense

translation.en: Not every man who says "Good night," sleeps together.
translation.creole: Na ebery man wah say "Goo' night," a-sleep togeddah

translation.en: Not everything that goes to the market is for sale.
translation.creole: Na eberyt'ing wah go a market fo' sell

translation.en: Not everything that has sugar is sweet.
translation.creole: Na eberyt'ing wah gat sugah a-sweet

translation.en: Not everything you see, should be spoken about.
translation.creole: Na eberyt'ing you see, mout' fo' talk

translation.en: Don't consider yourself a large barrel, when a butter keg can hold you.
translation.creole: Na fo'co youse'f a big puncheon, when buttah keg can hol' you

translation.en: It's not for lack of fire that peas take long to boil.
translation.creole: Na fo want ob fiah mek peas 'tan' lang fo bile

translation.en: It's not good to heat your neighbor's chair too much.
translation.creole: Na good fo' hot you matty chair too much

translation.en: Don't poke a stick in your friend's eye, or someone else will do it to you.
translation.creole: Na jook 'tick a-you matty yeye, no so somebody else go jook a-fo' you

translation.en: Don't let today spoil tomorrow.
translation.creole: Na leh to-day 'pile to-morrow

translation.en: Don't let the moonlight deceive you, and don't disrespect the dark night.
translation.creole: Na mek moonlight fool you, an' gie dark night saucy

translation.en: Don't let a full stomach fool you.
translation.creole: Na mek wan belly-full fool you

translation.en: Don't let sweet talk fool you.
translation.creole: Na mek sweet mout' fool you

translation.en: Don't let your eyes be bigger than your head.
translation.creole: Na mek you' aez pass you' head

translation.en: Not only monkeys make trousers and find they can't fit them.
translation.creole: Na monkey 'lone does mek trouses, and fin' he can't fit am

translation.en: Only a thief's dog barks at him.
translation.creole: Na only tief man daag bark 'pon

translation.en: Don't spread the tablecloth before the pot is done boiling.
translation.creole: Na 'pread table clot' befo' pat done bile

translation.en: Don't wear a long coat and smoke a cigar when you go to a water mamma dance.
translation.creole: Na put on long coat an' smoke cigah when you go a-watah mamma dance

translation.en: Don't put on Sunday clothes on a weekday.
translation.creole: Na put on Sunday clo'es 'pon week-a-day 'kin

translation.en: Don't put your hand in another person's saucepan.
translation.creole: Na shub you' han' a-matty saucepan

translation.en: Don't stop to roll up your stockings when you're running for the train.
translation.creole: Na 'tap fo' roll up 'tackin' when you a-run fo' train

translation.en: Don't judge people by their appearance.
translation.creole: No tek man by dem look

translation.en: Don't use me as your scapegoat.
translation.creole: Na tek me mek you' coo-coo pat

translation.en: Don't remove your guts and replace them with straw.
translation.creole: Na tek out you guts and put in 'traw

translation.en: Don't be embarrassed to shake hands with a poor person.
translation.creole: Na tek shame face shake cuckaba niggah han'

translation.en: Don't take your neighbor's eye to sleep with.
translation.creole: Na tek you matty yeye fo' sleep wid

translation.en: Don't throw away dirty water until you get clean.
translation.creole: Na t'row 'way dutty watah teh you get clean

translation.en: There's a dog named Pompey.
translation.creole: Na wan daag name Pompey

translation.en: Nancy doesn't like to catch marabunta (a type of ant) because it has a long sting.
translation.creole: Nancy no like fo' ketch marabuntah 'cause he gat lang 'ting

translation.en: Never is the day a canoe sinks at the shore.
translation.creole: Nebbah de day canoe bore punt

translation.en: Never eat crab-back and drink water.
translation.creole: Nebbah eat crab-back an' drink watah

translation.en: Never go at night to buy black cloth at the store.
translation.creole: Nebbah go a-night fo' buy black clat' a-'tore

translation.en: Never mind, it's why the estate doesn't have a back road.
translation.creole: Nebbah min'" mek estate no gat back-dam

translation.en: Never put out fire to fury
translation.creole: Nebbah out fiah to fury

translation.en: Never sell everything as you buy it.
translation.creole: Nebbah sell eberyt'ing as you buy am

translation.en: Never put your head where you know you can't get out.
translation.creole: Nebbah shub you' head weh you know you go fasten

translation.en: Never look for trouble until trouble comes to you.
translation.creole: Nebbah trouble trouble till trouble trouble you

translation.en: Never throw away today what you will want tomorrow.
translation.creole: Nebbah t'row 'way to-day wha' you go want to-morrow

translation.en: Never throw away your walking stick until you cross the river.
translation.creole: Nebbah t'row 'way you walking 'tiek teh you cross ribah

translation.en: Never try to make H turn into K.
translation.creole: Nebbah you try fo' mek H tu'n K

translation.en: As one person tries to rise, his fellow man pulls him down.
translation.creole: Niggah a-climb up, he matty a-pull he down

translation.en: The black man forgets, the white man remembers.
translation.creole: Niggah fo'get, Bacra 'membah

translation.en: The black man lives happily, he would greet the governor "good morning".
translation.creole: Niggah libe happy, he go tell gubnah "ma'nin'

translation.en: The black man says, "Wait first"; The Portuguese says, "Especially".
translation.creole: Niggah say, "Wait fus"; Potagee say, "Specalah

translation.en: The quality of the barrel doesn't improve the quality of the herring.
translation.creole: No bettah de barrel, no bettah de herrin'

translation.en: Nobody will beg when rain is coming.
translation.creole: Nobody go beg w'en rain da come

translation.en: Noise at the market doesn't mean it's a selling day.
translation.creole: Noise a-market no selling day

translation.en: If you don't catch it, you don't have it.
translation.creole: No ketchee, no habee

translation.en: No longer fiddle, no longer dance
translation.creole: No langah fiddle, no langah dance

translation.en: When a window isn't good, it makes a lot of noise when the wind blows.
translation.creole: When windah na good, 'e mek 'nough noise a-win'

translation.en: A foolish man uses a fork to eat soup.
translation.creole: Nonsense man tek fark fo' nyam soup

translation.en: No trick, no living.
translation.creole: No trick no libin'

translation.en: Now it's mango season; people can't sit still, they're always eating.
translation.creole: Now a mango season; matty no a-si' down matty doo' mout'

translation.en: Eat some, leave some for tomorrow.
translation.creole: Nyam some, lef' some fo' to-morrow

translation.en: Okra and cassava can't make soup in the same pot.
translation.creole: Ochro an' cassava can't mek soup a-wan pat

translation.en: An old fire-stick catches fire quickly.
translation.creole: Ol' fiah-'tick soon ketch

translation.en: Old grandmother swore at the caterpillar; the caterpillar swore to work his belly.
translation.creole: Ol' granny sweah fo' catapillah; catapillah sweah fo' wo'k he belly

translation.en: Old grudges make the bat lay eggs.
translation.creole: Ol' grudge mek bat lay egg

translation.en: Old grudges, new beatings
translation.creole: Ol' grudge, new licks

translation.en: Father works, child spends.
translation.creole: Faada wo'k picknie spen'

translation.en: Family conflicts don't cut deep.
translation.creole: Family cutlish na cut deep

translation.en: Pluck the fat chicken clean.
translation.creole: Fat fowl, pick am clean

translation.en: A long journey makes the okra dry on the tree.
translation.creole: Far-a-pa mek ochro dry a-tree

translation.en: Feast today, famine tomorrow
translation.creole: Feast to-day, famine to-morrow

translation.en: Fire and powder don't matter.
translation.creole: Fiah an' powdah no matty

translation.en: Fire is at the monkey's tail, he says "Cool breeze".
translation.creole: Fiah deh a-money tail he say "Cool breeze

translation.en: Without fire, the pot can't boil.
translation.creole: Fiah no deh, pat can't boil

translation.en: The finger never says "Look here," but "Look over there."
translation.creole: Fingah nebba say "Look yah," but "Look yandah

translation.en: The fish playing in the sea doesn't know that water is boiling for it.
translation.creole: Fish a-play a-sea, he no sabby watah a-bile fo' am

translation.en: A fisherman never says his own fish stinks.
translation.creole: Fishaman nebba say he own fish 'tink

translation.en: When the fish is asleep, its enemy cuts its tail.
translation.creole: Fish a-sleep, he matty a-cut he tail

translation.en: Don't you scratch a flea bite?
translation.creole: Flea bite, you no 'cratch?

translation.en: The fly says it's having fun, not knowing the spider is near.
translation.creole: Fly say ya pledja, he na' know spidah neah

translation.en: The fly sits down and shakes its foot, then says "There's a story before, there's a story behind."
translation.creole: Fly si' down an' shake he foot, den say "'Tory befo', 'tory behin'

translation.en: Following a pattern never leads to trouble.
translation.creole: Follow pattern nebba out ob trouble

translation.en: The pounded plantain is not for you, don't cut it deep.
translation.creole: Foo-foo na fo' you, na cut am deep

translation.en: It's for me, before me, but it's not for us.
translation.creole: Fo' me a-fo' me, but f'awe na fo' me

translation.en: A foolish man learns from a wise man's wisdom.
translation.creole: Foolish man a-learn sense man sense

translation.en: A foolish man talks, but doesn't listen.
translation.creole: Foolish man a-talk, but na a-listen

translation.en: A foolish man kills the cow, but a sensible man eats it.
translation.creole: Foolish man kill cow, sense man eat am

translation.en: A foolish man uses his fist to hammer a nail into a plank.
translation.creole: Foolish man tek cuff fo' knack nail a-plank

translation.en: The food I eat, I'm not giving you.
translation.creole: Food me eat me na gie you

translation.en: Because of this, because of this, I can't do better.
translation.creole: Fo' secka fo' secka me can't do bettah

translation.en: A chicken may hatch a duck, but it doesn't do what a duck does.
translation.creole: Fowl a-hatch duck, but he no a-do wha' duck a-do

translation.en: Chickens and ducks are not the same, but they sleep in the same pen.
translation.creole: Fowl an' duck no wan, but dem sleep a-wan pen

translation.en: The rooster may be foolish, but that doesn't make him a villain.
translation.creole: Fowl-cock a fool, but da na mek am villain

translation.en: The country of the fowl-cook has changed; man has not changed.
translation.creole: Fowl-cook country tu'n; man na tu'n

translation.en: The rooster heard that war was coming, so he climbed to the top of a tree and declared himself a lighthouse keeper.
translation.creole: Fowl-cook hear war a-come he climb a-tap tree say he a light-house keepah

translation.en: The chicken eats and wipes its beak on the ground; the dog licks the hand that feeds it.
translation.creole: Fowl eat an' wipe he mout' a-groun'; daag a-lick de han' wah feed am

translation.en: The chicken overlooks the corn, it's naughty.
translation.creole: Fowl eye pass co'n, he bad

translation.en: When the fowl gives a dance, the cockroach has no business being there.
translation.creole: Fowl gie dance, cockroach no bu'iness deh

translation.en: The chicken is happy, but the hawk catches it.
translation.creole: Fowl merry, hawk ketch am

translation.en: A hen doesn't miss her egg until she wants to sit on it.
translation.creole: Fowl no a-miss he egg teh he wan' fo' set

translation.en: The chicken says it's going to sleep early because it doesn't want trouble to find it.
translation.creole: Fowl say he a-sleep soon, 'cause he no wan' trouble fo' meet am

translation.en: The chicken sees the matapee (a long wicker sieve) and thinks it's a camoodi (a boa constrictor).
translation.creole: Fowl see matapee he say a camoodi

translation.en: When a chicken sees an ant's nest, it sharpens its claws.
translation.creole: Fowl see wood ants' nes', he sharpen he toe

translation.en: The chicken swears to hatch the rotten egg, and the rotten egg swears to spoil its skin.
translation.creole: Fowl swaer fo' hatch rotten egg, rotten egg swear fo' pile he 'kin'

translation.en: The chicken swears by its egg, not by its chick.
translation.creole: Fowl swear fo' him hegg, he no swear fo' him picknie

translation.en: A hen steps on her chicks, but she doesn't step hard.
translation.creole: Fowl tread 'pon he chicken, but he no tread haad

translation.en: What's for you is for you, what's for me is for me.
translation.creole: Fo' you a-fo you, fo' me a-fo' me

translation.en: For you and for us are not the same.
translation.creole: Fo' you an' fo' awe na wan

translation.en: A man with a full belly doesn't know what a hungry belly suffers.
translation.creole: Full belly man na know wha' hungry belly a-suffer

translation.en: The first jump is not a jump.
translation.creole: Fus' jump na jump

translation.en: The first laugh isn't the end.
translation.creole: Fus' laugh ain't de ending

translation.en: Girl, I love you because you have long black hair.
translation.creole: Gal me lobe you 'cause you got lotan hair

translation.en: A girl who doesn't listen to her mother's advice will find her mistake.
translation.creole: Gal wah no yery mamma 'tory sa larikary (find her mistake.)

translation.en: A gambling man walks with his liver in his hand.
translation.creole: Gamble man a-walk wid he libba a-he han'

translation.en: The game that a dog can play with a snake, it can't play it with an anteater.
translation.creole: Game wah daag a-play with sal'pentah, he can't play am wid ants-eater

translation.en: Get it for nothing, eat it in excess.
translation.creole: Get am fo' not'in' eat am fo' glutton

translation.en: A penny's worth of bread won't satisfy a man's hunger, but it will fill his mouth.
translation.creole: Gill bread na a-full man yeye, but he full he mout'

translation.en: A penny bread doesn't break a little Creole's mouth.
translation.creole: Gill bread na ha tear li'l creole mout'

translation.en: The goat is going along merrily, heading towards the pound.
translation.creole: Goat a-merry, a-pung he a-go

translation.en: Goats and sheep can't stay in the same pen.
translation.creole: Goat an' sheep can't 'tan' a-wan pen

translation.en: The goat is enjoying himself, he forgets that the knife is on the table.
translation.creole: Goat a-plesha, he fo'get knife a-table

translation.en: The goat is dead, but its skin is still useful.
translation.creole: Goat dead, but he 'kin sa mek down

translation.en: The goat is across the river, it's giving the tiger attitude.
translation.creole: Goat deh obah ribah, he gie tigah saucy

translation.en: The goat's foot is broken, but its mouth is not broken.
translation.creole: Gaot foot bruck, but he mout' no bruck

translation.en: Goat fears tiger, eye fears eye
translation.creole: Goat friken tigah, yeye friken yeye

translation.en: A goat's head and a sheep's head are not the same.
translation.creole: Goat head an' sheep head na wan

translation.en: The goat knows it can jump, that's why it climbs high places.
translation.creole: Goat know he can jump da mek he does climb high place

translation.en: The goat taught its kid to climb high places, then turned back and warned it that it would break its neck if it climbed there.
translation.creole: Goat la'n he picknie fo' climb a high place, den tu'n back tell am say he go bruck he nek if he climb deh

translation.en: A goat is sitting down grazing on a rope, while the small wild animal's mother is cooking sweet soup.
translation.creole: Goat si' down a rope a-graze, yawarri mamma cook sweet soup

translation.en: Trouble and the sea have no back door.
translation.creole: Trouble an' sea no gat no back doo

translation.en: God Almighty never sleeps.
translation.creole: God A'mighty nebba sleep

translation.en: God doesn't like ugliness.
translation.creole: God no like ugly

translation.en: A gold digger's money is blind.
translation.creole: Gol' diggah money na gat yeye fo' see

translation.en: Good calabash can't float in the river.
translation.creole: Good calabash can't float a-ribah

translation.en: A good hen lays eggs, what do you think of that?
translation.creole: Good fowl 'pile egg, wha' you t'ink a sensa?

translation.en: A good heart is what makes the world stand as it is today.
translation.creole: Good heart mek haag 'tan' so t'day

translation.en: Good reputation is like an egg, once it falls you can't pick it up.
translation.creole: Good libin' 'tan' like hegg, when he fall you can't pick am up

translation.en: Good men don't last long, but bad men live forever.
translation.creole: Good man no las' lang, but bad man libe fo' true

translation.en: I do good, but I see bad.
translation.creole: Good me do, bad me see

translation.en: A good woman can make sugar cake from a cayman's teeth.
translation.creole: Good ooman tek cayman teet' mek sugah cake

translation.en: Good sir stands like a rooster wanting to crow.
translation.creole: Good sahib 'tan' like a cock wan' crow

translation.en: A good thief becomes a good watchman.
translation.creole: Good tief man tu'n good watchman

translation.en: Good words are good, but good deeds are better.
translation.creole: Good word good, good deed bettah

translation.en: Grass is growing, but the horse is starving.
translation.creole: Grass a-grow, but haas a-'tarve

translation.en: Being too greedy can lead to one's downfall.
translation.creole: Greedy choke puppy

translation.en: A greedy person always goes to bed hungry.
translation.creole: Greedy man always sleep hungry

translation.en: A greedy man's eyes turn yellow twice.
translation.creole: Greedy man yeye yalla two time

translation.en: Greedy people get angry twice.
translation.creole: Greedy people does bex two time

translation.en: The green lime dropped, leaving the yellow one.
translation.creole: Green lime drap lef' yalla wan

translation.en: The governor doesn't know what he wants until he's hungry.
translation.creole: Gubnah no know he want till he hungry

translation.en: The guinea pig says he doesn't want a story, that's why he doesn't have a tail.
translation.creole: Guinea pig say he no wan' 'tory, da da mek he no gat tail

translation.en: A gunman can't stand up to kill all birds.
translation.creole: Gun man can't 'tan' up fo' kill all bi'd

translation.en: A gun doesn't know its own master.
translation.creole: Gun no know he own massa

translation.en: The gutter is running water, but there must be a bucket to catch it.
translation.creole: Guttah a-run watah, but pail mus' deh fo' ketch am

translation.en: A hog is born with a tail, but it can live without it.
translation.creole: Haag bo'n wid tail, but he can libe widout am

translation.en: A hog can't get fat without eating its offspring.
translation.creole: Haag can't fat birout he eat he pickin'

translation.en: Hog head and hog tail are not the same.
translation.creole: Haag head an haag tail na wan

translation.en: The doctor is not available.
translation.creole: Haag na gat dactah

translation.en: A horse in the pasture is not a horse in the stable.
translation.creole: Haas a-pastah na haas a-stable

translation.en: A horse is a strong creature, but a small stick can break its back.
translation.creole: Haas a 'trang somet'ing, but li'l 'tick bruck he back

translation.en: The horse gets credit for its running speed, the donkey for its kicking one.
translation.creole: Hass get credit fo' he runnin' foot, jackass fo' he kickin wan

translation.en: Having your own is better than being beholden.
translation.creole: Hab you' own bettah dan beholden

translation.en: Hard living makes a driver carry hog meat.
translation.creole: Ha'd libin' mek dribah carry haag meat

translation.en: Hard living makes the plower and the ibis feed in the same drain.
translation.creole: Ha'd libin' mek ploward an' gaulin' a-feed a-wan drain

translation.en: Hard times make a dog eat roasted corn.
translation.creole: Ha'd time mek daag nyam roas' co'n

translation.en: Hard times make a chicken catch fish in a trench.
translation.creole: Ha'd time mek fowl ketch fish a-trench

translation.en: The old guitar plays very nice tunes.
translation.creole: Ol' guitar play bery nice chune

translation.en: Old rat eats new cheese.
translation.creole: Ol' rat eat new cheese

translation.en: Old things are bringing new ones.
translation.creole: O tings a-bring new ones

translation.en: One egg can't produce two chickens.
translation.creole: One egg can't gie two chicken

translation.en: One finger can't catch lice.
translation.creole: One fingah can't ketch louse

translation.en: One fool makes many.
translation.creole: One fool mek many

translation.en: One man can't follow two calabashes.
translation.creole: One man can't falla two gooby

translation.en: One man makes a potato bank, everyone digs it.
translation.creole: One man mek patata bank, all man dig am

translation.en: One man's wealth makes too many men cry.
translation.creole: One man money mek too much man cry

translation.en: Little by little, dirt builds a dam.
translation.creole: One one dutty buil' dam

translation.en: What happened once can happen again.
translation.creole: One time nebbah done am

translation.en: Seeing something once could be a coincidence, but seeing it twice is intentional.
translation.creole: One time see sa do, but two time is purpose

translation.en: Only the cow knows why, and the fly feels sorry that God gave it a long tail.
translation.creole: Only cow know why, an' fly feel sarry God gie a long tail

translation.en: Only the knife knows what's in the pumpkin's belly.
translation.creole: Only knife know wha' deh a-punckin belly

translation.en: Women like to talk a lot, her pot is burning on the fire.
translation.creole: Ooman min' lang talk, he pat bu'n a-fiah

translation.en: A woman doesn't love a man, she says "There's no place."
translation.creole: Ooman na lobe man, he say "Place na deh

translation.en: Open your eyes, then you will understand the sense.
translation.creole: Open you yeye, you sa sabby sense

translation.en: An orange never falls too far from its tree.
translation.creole: Orange nebbah fall too far from he tree

translation.en: An orange is yellow, but you don't know if it's sweet.
translation.creole: Orange yalla, but you na know if he sweet

translation.en: Outside is water, inside is mud.
translation.creole: Out a-do watah, inside a-putto-putto

translation.en: Control your tongue, or it will get you into trouble.
translation.creole: Padlock you' tongue, or it lock you up

translation.en: A patient man can drive a donkey.
translation.creole: Patience man dribe jackass

translation.en: Patwa and ouri ran away, ouri said "Wait, we will meet at the stop-off."
translation.creole: Patwa an' ouri fetch away, ouri say " Wai' awe go meet a-'tap aff

translation.en: Paying late is worse than not paying at all.
translation.creole: Pay fus' mo' bad dan don't pay at all

translation.en: Payment is never lost.
translation.creole: Payman nebbah loss

translation.en: Pay today, trust tomorrow.
translation.creole: Pay to-day, trus' to-morrow

translation.en: If a child can't get their mother, they suckle from their grandmother.
translation.creole: Picknie can't get mamma, he suck granny

translation.en: If a child can't listen, they must learn through experience.
translation.creole: Picknie can't heah, he mus' feel

translation.en: The child died on purpose, the mother said she will bury him on purpose.
translation.creole: Picknie dead fo' prupose, mamma sa bury am prupose

translation.en: This time, the child has cut their eye teeth too soon.
translation.creole: Pieknie dis time cut dem yeye teet' too soon

translation.en: The child's head has lice, he doesn't want it to be combed.
translation.creole: Picknie head hab cra-cra, he no want am fo' comb

translation.en: The child knows how to run, but doesn't know how to hide.
translation.creole: Picknie niggah know fo' run, but na know fo' hide

translation.en: The child doesn't hear "Stay calm," they hear "Oh, poor thing."
translation.creole: Picknie no heah "'Tan' easy," he sa heah "Aow, poo' ting

translation.en: A child should not use his left hand to point out his father's poverty.
translation.creole: Picknie no tek lef' han' fo' t'row he daddy poverty

translation.en: The child pig asked its mother, "Why is your mouth so long?" The mother replied, "Wait child, you'll grow into it."
translation.creole: Picknie pig say to mamma, "Wha' mek you' mout' long so?" Mamma say, "Wai' chil', you a-come

translation.en: A child who doesn't listen to their mother's stories will leave their jacket at the door.
translation.creole: Picknie wah no yerry mamma 'tory he wan side jiggeh (jacket) go lef' a-doo'

translation.en: The pint pot is turned down, the gill pot is turned up.
translation.creole: Pint pot tu'n down, gill pot tu'n up

translation.en: A ripe plantain can't become unripe.
translation.creole: Plantain yalla can't come green

translation.en: Play with a monkey, but don't play with its tail.
translation.creole: Play wid monkey, but na play wid 'e tail

translation.en: Play with a puppy, and the puppy will lick your mouth.
translation.creole: Play wid puppy, puppy lick you mout'

translation.en: Play with a tiger's cub, but don't play with its mother.
translation.creole: Play wid tigah picknie, but na play wid 'e mamma

translation.en: There are many ways to kill a dog without putting a rope around its neck.
translation.creole: Plenty way deh fo choke dang widout hangin' rope roun' he neck

translation.en: Being poor is not a disease.
translation.creole: Poo' is no disesse

translation.en: A poor man is a rich man's slave.
translation.creole: Poo' man a-rich man slabe

translation.en: A poor man can't show his anger, but he thinks about it deeply.
translation.creole: Poo' man can't bex, but he t'ink it haad

translation.en: Poverty makes a man greedy.
translation.creole: Poo' mek man greedy

translation.en: The poor never feel sorry for themselves.
translation.creole: Poo' nebbah sorry fo' hese'f

translation.en: The pot is boiling, the man is laughing.
translation.creole: Pot bile, man laugh

translation.en: Promises gain friends; keeping them maintains the friendship.
translation.creole: Promise get frien'; perform keep am

translation.en: A promise is like a butterfly, if you put trust there, it will fly away from your hand.
translation.creole: Promise is butterfly, put trus' deh, you loss 'pan you' han'

translation.en: A pumpkin never bears a calabash.
translation.creole: Pumpkin nebbah bear calabash

translation.en: A pumpkin never makes white soup.
translation.creole: Pumpkin nebba mek white soup

translation.en: When the purse is full, there are plenty of friends.
translation.creole: Pu'se full, plenty frien'

translation.en:
English: Cat
Creole: Puss
translation.creole: Puss, cat

translation.en: A quick cent is better than a slow dollar.
translation.creole: Quick cent bettah mo' 'an slow dallah

translation.en: A rabbit's offspring never has short ears.
translation.creole: Rabbit pieknie aez nebbah cut

translation.en: Rain falls, the day shines, my grandmother Betsy's barrel is full.
translation.creole: Rain fall, day shine, me granny Betsy barrel a-full

translation.en: If the rain doesn't fill the jug, will the dew fill it?
translation.creole: Rain fall jug na full, dew sa full am?

translation.en: Rain causes sheep and goats to share the same pen.
translation.creole: Rain fall mek sheep an' goat a-wan pen

translation.en: When rain falls on a tiger, they call it a bush dog.
translation.creole: Rain fall wet tigah, dem call am bush-daag

translation.en: If it doesn't rain, grandma doesn't run.
translation.creole: Rain no fall, granny na run

translation.en: The ram goat doesn't cry for its horns, it cries for its life.
translation.creole: Ramgoat no cry fo' ho'n, he cry fo' libin'

translation.en: The ramgoat says he would rather his mother die than get wet from the afternoon rain.
translation.creole: Ramgoat say he soonah he mamma dead, befo' afternoon rain wet he

translation.en: The rat may forget, but the trap does not forget.
translation.creole: Rat a-fo'get, trap na fo'get

translation.en: The rat's tongue sold its head.
translation.creole: Ratta tongue sell he head

translation.en: Red ants are not crossing the river to look for ground ants.
translation.creole: Red dobe na a-obah ribah fo' look fo' groun' dobe

translation.en: Rice is boiling, the spoon is lost.
translation.creole: Rice bile, 'poon las'

translation.en: A rich man is sick, a poor man is drunk.
translation.creole: Rich man sick, poo' man drunk

translation.en: A rock at the bottom of the river doesn't feel the sun's heat.
translation.creole: Rock a-battam a-ribah no feel sun hot

translation.en: When the rum is gone, the fun is over.
translation.creole: Rum done, fun done

translation.en: Run from the coffin, you will end up with a ghost.
translation.creole: Run from coffin, you sa butt up wid jumby

translation.en: Run, rum, run, he is coming.
translation.creole: Run rum run he a-come

translation.en: Knowledge of something is always beneficial.
translation.creole: Sabby somet'ing does always deh behin' han'

translation.en: A soft heart leads to the destruction of industry.
translation.creole: Saf' haat mek Industry buil'in' bruck

translation.en: The quiet river runs deep
translation.creole: Saf'ly ribah run deep

translation.en: Safely, safely catch the monkey.
translation.creole: Saf'ly saf'ly ketch monkey

translation.en: Safely, safely fly down dog's ear.
translation.creole: Saf'ly saf'ly fly done daag ear

translation.en: Same as the master, same as the man.
translation.creole: Same like massa, same like man

translation.en: Service over church door locked
translation.creole: Sarvice obah chu'ch doo' lack

translation.en: A satisfied bird and a hungry bird can't fly together.
translation.creole: Satisfy bi'd an' hungry bi'd can't fly togeddah

translation.en: The satisfied bird tells the hungry bird "Wait a little bit".
translation.creole: Satisfy bi'd tell hungry bi'd " Wai' lil bit

translation.en: Because of sight, can't do better.
translation.creole: Seca fo' see can't do bettah

translation.en: Sell your pork where you get your fat.
translation.creole: Sell you' po'k weh you get you fat

translation.en: The frizzled chicken doesn't want feathers, it wants corn.
translation.creole: Sensa fowl na wan' feddah, him wan' co'n

translation.en: Short paths kill a man.
translation.creole: Shaat pa' a-kill man

translation.en: The shortcut breaks the dog's foot.
translation.creole: Shaat road a-bruck daag foot

translation.en: Shine your boots first before you shine your friend's one.
translation.creole: Shine you' boots fus' befo' you shine you' matty wan

translation.en: Only shoes know if socks have holes.
translation.creole: Shoes alone know if 'tockin's hab holes

translation.en: The sick mother is calling because she wants to hear your voice.
translation.creole: Sick mamma call, 'cause he want ketch you' voice

translation.en: A sick man looks for a doctor.
translation.creole: Sick man look fo' dactah

translation.en: Sickness may end, but trickery never ceases.
translation.creole: Sick sa done, but trick can't done

translation.en: Silk and scarlet are seen, mother.
translation.creole: Silk and 'carlet a-sin mamma

translation.en: Nothing is more bitter than gall.
translation.creole: Sin bittah mo' dan gall

translation.en: Since "Excuse me" became a trend, a little boy steps on a grown man's foot.
translation.creole: Since Beg paadon" come a-fashion, li'l boy mash big man foot

translation.en: Since the indigenous person's hut burned, there has been no fair play.
translation.creole: Since Buck benab bu'n, fai' play no deh

translation.en: The pot can't tell the kettle that its bottom is black.
translation.creole: Skillet can't tell pat say 'e battam black

translation.en: Slow actions lead to serious consequences.
translation.creole: Slow motion bring heavy come down

translation.en: A snake's offspring doesn't know its name until it goes to the dam.
translation.creole: Snake picknie na know 'e name teh 'e go a-dam

translation.en: If someone doesn't work, they don't eat the master's plantain.
translation.creole: Somebody no walk, he no eat massa plantain

translation.en: Some goats run from dogs, but some confront them.
translation.creole: Some goat a-run from daag, but some a-put he handle 'pon am

translation.en: Some people are fattening pigs for their neighbors to eat.
translation.creole: Some man a-fatten haag fo' dem matty eat

translation.en: Sometimes a white face carries a black heart.
translation.creole: Sometimes white face carry black haat

translation.en: Something more than cane made him turn into sugar.
translation.creole: Somet'ing mo' dan cane mek he tu'n sugah

translation.en: The soup is cold, the dog put its mouth there.
translation.creole: Soup col', daag put mout' deh

translation.en: There's no pork in the soup itself.
translation.creole: Soup po'k no deh da se'f

translation.en: A man is not ashamed of sour grass.
translation.creole: Sour grass a man no a-shame

translation.en: If you spit in the sky, it will fall on your face.
translation.creole: Spit a-de sky, he sa fall a-you' face

translation.en: A spiteful man is like a cow's dung, hard on top but soft at the bottom.
translation.creole: Spiteful man like cow-down, haad a-tap, saf' a-battam

translation.en: A spiteful man puts pepper in his mouth to blow dirt into his neighbor's eyes.
translation.creole: Spiteful man put peppah da-he mout' fo' blow dutty out a-he matty yeye

translation.en: Silence is the sign of wisdom.
translation.creole: Still tongue keep wise head

translation.en: A stranger doesn't know the burial ground.
translation.creole: Stranger no know berrin' groun'

translation.en: Sucking teeth and rolling eyes can offend a man.
translation.creole: Suck teet' an' cut yeye tek aff 'pon a man

translation.en: A sugar barrel never kills ants.
translation.creole: Sugah haagshead nebbah kill hanch

translation.en: The sun is hot today, it could cause a heat stroke.
translation.creole: Sun hot da-wha, a stroke man

translation.en: Don't curse a mangy dog until the sun goes down.
translation.creole: Sun na down, na cuss mangy daag

translation.en: As long as the sun hasn't set, a man's troubles aren't over.
translation.creole: Sun no down, man no done cry

translation.en: If he doesn't finish today, he will finish tomorrow.
translation.creole: Suppose he no done to-day, he sa done to-morrow

translation.en: Sweet heart is like sweet bread, you eat it and it's gone.
translation.creole: Sweet haat a-sweet bread, you nyam am he done

translation.en: Sweet words bring the runaway home.
translation.creole: Sweet mout' bring runaway niggah home

translation.en: Sweet oranges aren't falling to the ground.
translation.creole: Sweet orange no a-fall a-groun'

translation.en: Sweet soup makes you eat sour foofoo.
translation.creole: Sweet soup mek you eat sour foofoo

translation.en: Talk is the last food.
translation.creole: Talk is de las' food

translation.en: Talking this and talking that, never mind your own business.
translation.creole: Talkin' dis an' talkin' dat, nebbah peep a-you matty pat

translation.en: Speak of the devil and you hear his wings.
translation.creole: Talk ob de debil an you heah he wings

translation.en: Stand farther, see better
translation.creole: 'Tan' farra, see bettah

translation.en: "Standing safely is better than begging for pardon."
translation.creole: 'Tan' saf'ly bettah dan beg paadon

translation.en: The stop-off broke, the fish got away.
translation.creole: 'Tap-aff bruck, fish get 'way

translation.en: Tar rope and a man's back do not get along.
translation.creole: Tar rope an' man back na agree

translation.en: Teeth and tongue must bite.
translation.creole: Teet' an' tongue mus' bite

translation.en: Thank you killed my grandmother's cat.
translation.creole: Tenkee kill me granny cat

translation.en: The same tongue that drives a cow into a pen, doesn't drive it out.
translation.creole: The same tongue that drive cow a-pen, no so drive him out

translation.en: The quietest calf drinks the most milk.
translation.creole: The stillest calf sucks the longest draught

translation.en: Stealing from a thief makes God Almighty laugh.
translation.creole: Tief from tief mek Garamighty laugh

translation.en: Time for mule, time for long chain
translation.creole: Time fo' mule, time fo' lang chain

translation.en: A thief and a dog are not friends.
translation.creole: Tief man an' daag na frien'

translation.en: A thief doesn't like to see his friend walking with a big bag.
translation.creole: Tief man no like fo' see he matty walk with big bag

translation.en: Thieves do not like the moon.
translation.creole: Tief man no like moon

translation.en: When the tiger feels fire on his tail, he cries out for a cool breeze.
translation.creole: Tigah feel fiah a-he tail, he halla fo' cool breeze

translation.en: The tiger sends the dog, the dog sends its tail.
translation.creole: Tigah sen' daag, daag sen' he tail

translation.en: The tiger stole corn, he got his skin marked.
translation.creole: Tigah tief co'n, he get he 'kin mark

translation.en: The tiger wants to catch the rooster, he tells him the country is in turmoil.
translation.creole: Tigah wan' fo' ketch fowlcock, he tell am country tu'n

translation.en: Time is passing by, but it's not coming back.
translation.creole: Time a-go 'way, but he no a-come back

translation.en: Don't wake something that is sleeping.
translation.creole: T'ing a-sleep, no wake am

translation.en: Things happen that cause a cow to abandon its calf.
translation.creole: T'ing deh fo' mek cow run lef' he calf

translation.en: Today for you, tomorrow for me.
translation.creole: To-day fo' you, to-morrow fo' me

translation.en: The tongue doesn't have teeth, but it can bite for sure.
translation.creole: Tongue na gat teet', but he bite fo' true

translation.en: Tom is drunk, but Tom is not a fool.
translation.creole: Tom drunk, but Tom no fool

translation.en: There's too much of the old stump to be easily burned by fire.
translation.creole: Too much a ol' 'tump to be easily bu'n by fiah

translation.en: Too much fake smiling is not genuine laughter.
translation.creole: Too much 'kin teet' no laugh

translation.en: Too many rats don't dig a deep hole.
translation.creole: Too much ratta don't dig deep hole

translation.en: Too much salt spoils your soup.
translation.creole: Too much sal' 'pile you' soup

translation.en: Too many torn trousers on the side.
translation.creole: Too much side bruck trouses

translation.en: Sitting down too much wears out your pants.
translation.creole: Too much si' down bruck breeches

translation.en: Too much water doesn't make good soup.
translation.creole: Too much watah no mek good soup

translation.en: "What is said doesn't burden your stomach."
translation.creole: 'Tory a-mout no load you' 'tomach

translation.en: The secret is out as soon as you tell a woman.
translation.creole: Tory bus' as you leh woman know

translation.en: The story is old, it's not interesting.
translation.creole: Tory ol', he no sweet

translation.en: Three silver fish can't make one Congo fish.
translation.creole: Tree silver fish cant mek one Congo fish

translation.en: Experience brings wisdom
translation.creole: Trial makes mention

translation.en: Trouble is in the bush, but the monkey brings it home.
translation.creole: Trouble a-deh a-bush, a monkey a-bring am a-house

translation.en: Trouble arrives swiftly like on horseback, but it leaves slowly as if on foot.
translation.creole: Trouble come 'pon horseback, he go 'way 'pon foot

translation.en: Trouble walks on legs, scandal has wings.
translation.creole: Trouble go 'pon legs, 'candal hab wings

translation.en: Trouble makes an old woman trot.
translation.creole: Trouble mek ol' ooman trat

translation.en: Trouble must knock at every man's door at some point.
translation.creole: Trouble mus' knack at all man doo' mout'

translation.en: Trouble doesn't announce itself like rain does.
translation.creole: Trouble no set like rain

translation.en: Throw a rock at a hog's sty, the hog cries "Quee," that's the one it hit.
translation.creole: T'row rockstone a-haag 'ty, haag cry "Quee," dá him it knack

translation.en: Try your boots first before you give another man to stretch them.
translation.creole: Try you' boots fus' befo' you gie naddah man fo' 'tretch am

translation.en: Two captains can't steer one ship.
translation.creole: Two cap'n can't 'teer wan ship

translation.en: Two hills can't meet together, but two people can.
translation.creole: Two hill can't meet togeddah, but two man can

translation.en: Two men are having a long conversation.
translation.creole: Two man a-mek lang 'tory

translation.en: Two sensible men can't live in one house.
translation.creole: Two sense man can't libe a-wan house

translation.en: Two sensible men can't change a half-penny.
translation.creole: Two sense man can't change half-bitt

translation.en: Two things are racing, one must win.
translation.creole: Two t'ing a-run, one must' win

translation.en: An ugly face doesn't mean an ugly heart.
translation.creole: Ugly face no ugly heart

translation.en: Ugly told Handsome, "Scare this away for me."
translation.creole: Ugly tell han'some, "Friken dis fo' me

translation.en: A man who is unwilling must suffer the consequences.
translation.creole: Unwillin' man nose mus' bleed

translation.en: If the barrel isn't opened often enough, dry weather feels like rainy weather.
translation.creole: Vat no a-open 'nough time, dry weddah like rain weddah

translation.en: What is coming, wait, you will see it.
translation.creole: Wah a-come, wai', you sa see am

translation.en: What one cries, that one feels it.
translation.creole: Wah a-cry, á dem a-feel am

translation.en: Whoever is lucky will win.
translation.creole: Wah gat luck sa win

translation.en: What doesn't have feet must go first.
translation.creole: Wah na gat foot mus' go befo'

translation.en: Walking aimlessly is better than sitting idly.
translation.creole: Walk fo' not'in' bettah dan si' down fo' not'in'

translation.en: A wasteful man's money disappears as quickly as butter against the sun.
translation.creole: Was'eful man money go like buttah 'gainst de sun

translation.en: Wash your own face before you wash another's.
translation.creole: Wash you' own face befo' you wash you' matty wan

translation.en: Clean your own wounds before you look at your neighbor's.
translation.creole: Wash you' own sore befo' you look you' matty wan

translation.en: Water puts out fire.
translation.creole: Watah a-out fiah

translation.en: Water doesn't stay in a jar for no reason.
translation.creole: Watah no a-'tink a-jar fo' not'in'

translation.en: Water has no bottom.
translation.creole: Watah no gat battam

translation.en: Water thrown away doesn't break the jug
translation.creole: Watah t'row 'way jug no broke

translation.en: Water thrown on the ground can't be picked up again.
translation.creole: Watah t'row way na groun' can't pick up again

translation.en: The water that flowed in the river last year is not the same as this year's.
translation.creole: Watah wah run a-ribah las' yeah na a-run dis yeah

translation.en: Water washes, water falls.
translation.creole: Watah wash, watah fall

translation.en: Watch the lion, but don't let it watch you.
translation.creole: Watch lion, but na mek he watch you

translation.en: The wattle house has ears.
translation.creole: Wattle 'ouse gat yase

translation.en: Where the cow is tied, that's where it grazes.
translation.creole: Weh cow tie, á-deh he a-graze

translation.en: Where the horse goes, the donkey will go too.
translation.creole: Weh haas go, jackass sa go too

translation.en: Where there is a lot of water, more water flows.
translation.creole: Weh plenty watah deh mo' watah run

translation.en: Where the top is weak, that's where a goat will break through.
translation.creole: Weh tap-off weak á-deh a goat does bore

translation.en: Well, can't leave well enough alone.
translation.creole: Well can't let bery well alone

translation.en: What is going, let it go.
translation.creole: Wha' a-go, leh he go

translation.en: The donkey said, "Ah! If there were no laws, there would be too many stories."
translation.creole: Jackass say "Ah! if no bin a law, too much 'tory

translation.en: Jail is not made for dogs, it's made for people.
translation.creole: Jail no mek fo' daag, he mek fo' people

translation.en: Begging leads to stealing.
translation.creole: Jango beg, jango kill

translation.en: Jimbo says Every man is responsible for his own actions.
translation.creole: Jimbo say Ebery man 'kin he own teet

translation.en: Joseph isn't here to light a fire for everyone; he lights a fire for those who do the same for him.
translation.creole: Joseph no come fo blow fiah fo' eberybody; who blow fish fo'he, he blow fo' dem

translation.en: The ghost bird cries a funeral today.
translation.creole: Jumby bi'd halla funeral a-day

translation.en: Ghost okra can't make a sweet soup.
translation.creole: Jumby calalu can't mek sweet soup

translation.en: Ghosts like white cloth.
translation.creole: Jumby like white clat'

translation.en: A ghost never saw salt; it swears it's sugar.
translation.creole: Jumby nebba see sal'; he swear a-sugah

translation.en: The ghost sends a spirit; the spirit sends its waiting boy.
translation.creole: Jumby sen' spirit; spirit sen' he waiting boy

translation.en: Jump, jump, the tradesman's hand opens on Saturday.
translation.creole: Jump jump trademan han' open 'pon Satu'day

translation.en: Kick and hit just like a knock.
translation.creole: Kick an' cuff same knack

translation.en: Kill a child, give it to the mother, the mother won't eat it; kill the mother, give it to the child, the child will eat it.
translation.creole: Kill pieknie, gie mamma, mamma no go eat am; kill mamma gie picknie, picknie go eat am

translation.en: Kiskadee on the back of a cow
translation.creole: Kiskadee on cowback

translation.en: The kitchen dresser fell down, the skinny dog laughed.
translation.creole: Kitchen dressah fall down, magah daag laugh

translation.en: Knock hard, the child is scared.
translation.creole: Knock daddy heaby, pieknie sa friken

translation.en: Long conversations led them to catch the runaway person.
translation.creole: Lang discou'se mek dem ketch runaway niggah

translation.en: A long-nosed dog can't blow fire.
translation.creole: Lang nose daag can't blow fiah

translation.en: The long story is that the turtle doesn't want to carry its shell on its back.
translation.creole: Lang 'tory tu'tle no wan' mek he carry he trunk a-he back

translation.en: An educated man walks carefully, an uneducated man makes noise.
translation.creole: Larnid man walk saf'ly, unlarnid man keep nise

translation.en: A lazy person always has a lot of work.
translation.creole: Lazy man always get 'nough wo'k

translation.en: A lazy man's belly is never satisfied.
translation.creole: Lazy man belly neba sa full

translation.en: When a leaf falls into the water, it doesn't rot immediately.
translation.creole: Leaf fall a-watah, he no rotten wan time

translation.en: Fewer guests, fewer dirty dishes.
translation.creole: Less company, less dutty plate

translation.en: Lies have no legs.
translation.creole: Lie hab no legs

translation.en: Lies more than fire burns.
translation.creole: Lie mo' dan fiah-bu'n

translation.en: The little boy is impressing the grown man.
translation.creole: Li'l boy a-swell big man yeye

translation.en: A little boy doesn't climb a ladder to become a big man.
translation.creole: Li'l boy na a-climb laddah fo' tu'n big man

translation.en: The little finger says "Look over there," but the thumb says "Look here."
translation.creole: Li'l fingah say "Look yandah," bing t'umb say "Look yah

translation.en: A little fun is better than a whole gun.
translation.creole: Li'l fun bettah mo' dan whole gun

translation.en: Small garden, but bitter weed
translation.creole: Li'l garden, but bittah weed

translation.en: Small shoe, big shoe, same price; give him the big shoe.
translation.creole: Li'l juta, big juta, same money; gie am big juta

translation.en: A small trench can hold a big fish.
translation.creole: Li'l trench a-hol' in big fish

translation.en: A limb can't stand without a tree.
translation.creole: Limb can't 'tan berout tree

translation.en: Lime never tastes sweet
translation.creole: Lime nebba tas'e sweet

translation.en: A free goat doesn't understand what a tied-up goat feels.
translation.creole: Loose-goat na a-feel wha' tie-goat a-feel

translation.en: Luck is better than being handsome.
translation.creole: Luck mo' bettah dan han'some

translation.en: The macaw asked the parrot if the pajarra fruit was ripe, and it replied "One, one."
translation.creole: Maccaw ask parrot pajarra ripe, he say "Wan, wan

translation.en: A man who is courting must dress well.
translation.creole: Man a-cou'tin' mus' go gay

translation.en: The manager's cow says, "The white man's work is never done."
translation.creole: Manaja cow say, "Bacra wo'k nebba done

translation.en: The manager's horse eats good oats.
translation.creole: Manaja haas nyam good oats

translation.en: The manager is withholding the coolie's money, but when the coolie is preparing for the Tadja festival, the manager is the first to open his mouth because he is participating.
translation.creole: Manaja 'tap coolie money, but when coolie mek tadja, a-manaja doo' mout' fus' he a-play

translation.en: A man always looks for what he doesn't want to see.
translation.creole: Man always look fo' wha' he no wan' fo' see

translation.en: A man saw the monkey's neck before he put a chain around its waist.
translation.creole: Man bin see monkey neck befo' he put chain a-he waist

translation.en: A man bought a big-bellied horse, he wants it to cut grass.
translation.creole: Man buy big belly haas, he wan ha' fo cut grass

translation.en: A man can't do better; he says "No matter".
translation.creole: Man can't do bettah; he say "No mattah

translation.en: A man can't get the pamawarri (a prickly bush rope) if he's afraid that its thorns will prick him.
translation.creole: Man can't get pamawarri if he friken he pimplah go chook am

translation.en: A man can run, but a man can't hide.
translation.creole: Man can run, but man can't hide

translation.en: A man cuts his timber so he can haul it.
translation.creole: Man cut he timbah sa haul am

translation.en: When a man dies, grass grows at his door.
translation.creole: Man dead, grass grow a-he doo'

translation.en: When a man dies, he is truly dead.
translation.creole: Man die, he die fo' true

translation.en: After the meal is cooked, the spoon is the last thing to be used.
translation.creole: Man done cook, spoon las'

translation.en: If the man is drunk and the woman is drunk, who will close the door?
translation.creole: Man drunk, ooman drunk, who fo' shut de doo'

translation.en: A man with manners, he has a lot of pounded plantain.
translation.creole: Man gat mannas, he get big foofoo

translation.en: A man may be smart, but a horse can still kick him.
translation.creole: Man gat sense, but haas can kick am

translation.en: If a man talks too much, he will pay for his father's mistakes.
translation.creole: Man gat too much tongue, he pay he daddy debt

translation.en: A man has two houses, yet he sleeps hungry.
translation.creole: Man gat two 'ouse, he sleep hungry

translation.en: A man has two eyes, but can't look in two places at once.
translation.creole: Man gat two yeye, but can't look a-two place

translation.en: A man's hand makes twine, but the twine turns back to tie his hand.
translation.creole: Man han' a-mek twine, but twine a-tu'n back tie he han'

translation.en: A bad name in the morning is better than one in the afternoon.
translation.creole: Ma'nin' bad name bettah mo' 'an aftanoon wan

translation.en: When a man hits iron, the iron doesn't feel it, but when iron hits a man, the man feels it.
translation.creole: Man knack iron, iron na a-feel am, iron knack man, man a-feel am

translation.en: A man knows his weakness, he refuses the challenge of a strong man.
translation.creole: Man know he weak, he refuse 'trang man challenge

translation.en: People may know your face, but they don't know your heart.
translation.creole: Man know you' face, but he na know you' haat

translation.en: A man makes a coffin, but he doesn't want to go there.
translation.creole: Man mek coffin, but he no like a-go deh

translation.en: One must pay to gain wisdom.
translation.creole: Man mus' pay fo' larn sense

translation.en: A man must see his wife first before he buys a bed.
translation.creole: Man mus' see he wife fus' befo' he buy bed

translation.en: A man is not a thief until the watchman catches him.
translation.creole: Man na a tief teh watchman ketch am

translation.en: A man doesn't know what trouble is, until he has too much trouble.
translation.creole: Man na know a trouble, but he know too much a trouble

translation.en: A man doesn't appreciate his mother until she is dead.
translation.creole: Man na know he mamma use teh he dead

translation.en: A man's dreams are not over until he is done sleeping.
translation.creole: Man no done sleep, he no done dream

translation.en: If a man doesn't have feet, he can't walk.
translation.creole: Man no gat foot, he can't walk

translation.en: If a man doesn't like you, he'll give you a basket to fetch water.
translation.creole: Man no like you, he gie you basket fo' fetch watah

translation.en: If a man is not accustomed to chocolate, he says he won't drink it.
translation.creole: Man no nuse (used to) chacklit, he say he no a drink am

translation.en: If a man doesn't speak, news can't spread.
translation.creole: Man no talk, news can't go

translation.en: When a man is satisfied, he stops eating.
translation.creole: Man satisfy, he bore pat

translation.en: A man sees a calabash, but he doesn't know what's inside.
translation.creole: Man see gooby, but he na know wha' deh inside

translation.en: If a man talks too much, he pays his father's debt.
translation.creole: Man talk too much, he pay he daddy debt

translation.en: A man who starts before he's ready won't achieve good results.
translation.creole: Man 'tart befo' he ready can't meet good

translation.en: A man can predict his friend's fortune, but can't predict his own.
translation.creole: Man tell he matty farchin, but can't tell he own

translation.en: A man takes care of his own bed, he doesn't care about it because it's true, his neighbor cares for it for him.
translation.creole: Man tek row a-dam bed he na care am true, he matty care am fo❜ am

translation.en: If a man wants to drink rum, he says you should taste brandy to give him an appetite.
translation.creole: Man wan' fo' drink rum, he say yah tas'e brandy fo' gie am appetite

translation.en: A man who has a bottle on the table has many friends.
translation.creole: Man wah got bottle a-table got plenty frien'

translation.en: A man who wants to learn, will not find it hard to find a chapter.
translation.creole: Man wah know book, na haad fo' fin' chaptah

translation.en: A man without sense is like a bucket without a bottom.
translation.creole: Man wah na gat sense 'tan' like bucket berout battam

translation.en: A man who wants two wives must have two tongues.
translation.creole: Man wah wan' two wife mus' hab two tongue

translation.en: A man's weapon is his fist, a woman's weapon is her tongue.
translation.creole: Man weapon a-he fist, woman weapon a-he tongue

translation.en: A sensible man won't put his head in a hole.
translation.creole: Man wid sense na go shub he head a-hole

translation.en: The Marabunta (a type of ant) can bite, but it can't bite a spider.
translation.creole: Marabuntah a bite, but he can't bite nancy

translation.en: Being married doesn't guarantee that he is stable.
translation.creole: Married na sure he gat foot

translation.en: Marriage has teeth, it bites like a crab.
translation.creole: Married gat teet', he bite like crab

translation.en: There's no back door in marriage.
translation.creole: Married no got back doo.'

translation.en: Master's bull, master's cow
translation.creole: Massa bull, massa cow

translation.en: The master's servant is in a blanket.
translation.creole: Massa niggah a-blanket

translation.en: Matty lost his dog, his neighbor's corn field is full.
translation.creole: Matty loss he haag, he neighbah co'n-jah full

translation.en: Neighbor, what you want, you want to hide.
translation.creole: Matty wan you wan', you' wan you hide

translation.en: Neighbor, something sweet for you is bitter to others.
translation.creole: Matty somet'ing sweet fo you own bittah

translation.en: I am fire, I can't stand in a bag.
translation.creole: Me a fiah, me can't 'tan' a-bag

translation.en: I used to be a good dancer, but chigoe fleas ruined my foot.
translation.creole: Me bin a good dance man, but chiggah 'pile me foot

translation.en: I bought my calico, I must wear it.
translation.creole: Me buy me calico, me mus' wear am

translation.en: I'm already a dead dog, I don't care to think.
translation.creole: Me dead haag a'ready, me no ca' fo' 'tink

translation.en: The dog is skinny but its head is big.
translation.creole: Daag magah he head big

translation.en: Dog doesn't eat dog
translation.creole: Daag no nyam daag

translation.en: The dog says he keeps his dreams in his belly because he doesn't know how to talk.
translation.creole: Daag say he sa keep he dream a-he belly 'cause he no know fo' talk

translation.en: The dog set a trap to catch the hare, he fastened it himself.
translation.creole: Daag set trap fo' ketch accouri, he fasten dey hese'f

translation.en: The dog stuck his head in the salmon pot, he said he's seeing how the world goes round.
translation.creole: Daag shub he head a-salmon pat, he sa see how de world a-go roun'

translation.en: The dog trusts his feet, that's why he can be impudent to the tiger.
translation.creole: Daag trus' he foot mek he gie tigah saucy

translation.en: The dog that barks a lot runs away when it's time to bite.
translation.creole: Daag wah a-bark plenty a-run 'way time fo' bite

translation.en: The dog that brings a bone will carry it away.
translation.creole: Daag wah a-bring a bone sa, carry am

translation.en: The dog that eats what its friend left is never strong.
translation.creole: Daag wah a-eat wha' he matty lef' nebba 'trang

translation.en: A dog that is used to sucking eggs can't stop.
translation.creole: Daag wah use fo' suck egg can't lib (leave) off

translation.en: A dog walks on a dead lion.
translation.creole: Daag walk 'pon dead lion

translation.en: The dog wants to see a bonfire, so he throws grass on the fire's coals.
translation.creole: Daag wan' fo' see banfiah, he t'row grass 'pon fiah coal

translation.en: That foolish man wears a ring in his nose.
translation.creole: Da chupit man wear ring a-he nose

translation.en: That greedy person is always eating his food.
translation.creole: Da craben always a-eat a-pat

translation.en: The doctor doesn't know what's hurting you until you tell him.
translation.creole: Dactah na a-know weh a hu't you teh you tell am

translation.en: Doctor's medicine is always good.
translation.creole: Dactah physic always good

translation.en: A dainty dog will eat dirty pudding.
translation.creole: Dainty daag nyam dutty puddin'

translation.en: That lazy donkey can't carry his own oats.
translation.creole: Da lazy jackass can't carry he own oats

translation.en: The movement that rice has in a pot, it doesn't have on a plate.
translation.creole: Da motion wah rice got a-pot, he no got a-plate

translation.en: The same mouth a man uses to court a woman to bring her into his house, is the same mouth he uses to put her out the door.
translation.creole: Da mout' man tek fo cou'tin ooman fo' put am a-he house, a na da same mout' he a-tek fo' put am a-doo'

translation.en: The horse arrived at that place, and the donkey arrived safely too.
translation.creole: Da-place hass meet, safly safly jackass sa meet

translation.en: Wherever you see molasses, you're sure to see a blue fly.
translation.creole: Da place you see molasses, you sure fo' see blue fly

translation.en: The place where I live, it's really good.
translation.creole: Da place weh 1ibin', deh 'tan' foo good

translation.en: Go back to the place where the thorn pricked your foot to remove it.
translation.creole: Da place weh pimplah bore you foot, go back deh go tek am out

translation.en: Dark night has no governor.
translation.creole: Dark night hab no gubnah

translation.en: Dark night makes a fly boil soup.
translation.creole: Dark night mek fly boil a-soup

translation.en: The thing that pleases the goat is what kills it.
translation.creole: Da t'ing wah sweeten goat, a da a-kill am

translation.en: What you see in the daytime, don't use a torch to look for it at night.
translation.creole: Da somet'ing you a-see a-day time, no tek fiah 'tick a-night fo' look am

translation.en: A dead chicken brings money.
translation.creole: Dead chicken bring dallah

translation.en: Death is in the horse's eye, but he doesn't care for his master.
translation.creole: Dead deh a-hass eye, he no ca' fo' he massa

translation.en: The death is not over, the crying is not over.
translation.creole: Dead no done, cry no done

translation.en: Death seems to forget him.
translation.creole: Dead seem fo' fo'get he

translation.en: The devil tempts, but he does not force.
translation.creole: Debil a-tempt, but he no a-fo'ce

translation.en: The devil isn't bothered by the fact that he is painted black.
translation.creole: Debil bad no see he paint am black

translation.en: The longest prayer has an amen.
translation.creole: De langes' pray got a amen

translation.en: The same hammer that drives the nail in can take it out.
translation.creole: De same hammah wah dribe nail sa tek am out

translation.en: Dig a hole to fill a hole.
translation.creole: Dig a hole fo' full a hole

translation.en: This is saying one thing after another, until a story is formed.
translation.creole: Dis a-tell tarra, tara narra, till 'tory come

translation.en: Things are not like they used to be.
translation.creole: Dis time no like befo' time

translation.en: An eye for an eye is not witchcraft.
translation.creole: Do fo' do no obeah

translation.en: "Don't worry," maintain a large household.
translation.creole: Don' ca'e," keep big house

translation.en: Don't let your tail pass your head.
translation.creole: Don' mek you tail pass you head

translation.en: Don't judge my story by your own standards and weight.
translation.creole: Don' weigh me 'tory by you own 'cale an' weight

translation.en: What you do, is not what you love.
translation.creole: Do so no lobe so

translation.en: Downfall is not for one man.
translation.creole: Downfall no fo' wan man

translation.en: The driver is not playing Creole music.
translation.creole: Dribah na deh creole a-play

translation.en: Drive the yellow cow, the black one must run.
translation.creole: Dribe yalla cow, black wan mus' run

translation.en: Drink rum in your mouth, it says fly in your head.
translation.creole: Drink rum a-you mout', he sa f1y a-you head

translation.en: A drunk man never knows he's drunk.
translation.creole: Drunk man nebba know he drunk

translation.en: A drunk man says to a lamp post, "Excuse me, sir."
translation.creole: Drunk man tell lantern pos', "ask paadon, sah

translation.en: Dry wood is burning and green wood is burning too.
translation.creole: Dry wood a-bu'n an' green wood a-bu'n too

translation.en: The duck has water to wash its skin, the chicken wants it to drink.
translation.creole: Duck hab watah fo' was' he 'kin, fowl want am fo' drink

translation.en: Dirty water can put out fire.
translation.creole: Dutty watah can out fiah

translation.en: Dirty water cools the kettle
translation.creole: Dutty watah cool cappah

translation.en: What the ear doesn't hear, the eye will see.
translation.creole: Ear no yery, yeye sa see

translation.en: Easy come, easy go.
translation.creole: Easy get easy spen'

translation.en: What comes easily doesn't cause pain.
translation.creole: Easy squeeze no feel hurt

translation.en: Not every full belly is satisfied.
translation.creole: Ebery belly-full no a pat full

translation.en: Everyone feels their own pain.
translation.creole: Eberybody feel he own pain

translation.en: Every captain is the master of his own boat.
translation.creole: Ebery cap'n bass he own boat

translation.en: Every rooster crows at his own door, mouth.
translation.creole: Ebery cock crow a-he own doo, mout'

translation.en: Every cow cries for its own calf.
translation.creole: Ebery cow cry fo' he own calf

translation.en: Every dog is biting its master's door.
translation.creole: Ebery daag a-bite da-he massa doo'

translation.en: Every dog has its day.
translation.creole: Ebery daag ha' he day

translation.en: Every donkey thinks he's good enough to rank with the governor's horse.
translation.creole: Ebery donkey t'ink hese'f good fo' rank wid gubnah hass

translation.en: Every day the bucket goes to the well, one day its bottom will fall out.
translation.creole: Ebery day bucket go a-well, wan day he battam sa lef'

translation.en: Every day the devil helps the thief; one day God must help the watchman.
translation.creole: Ebery day debil help tief; wan day God mus' help watchman

translation.en: Every day is a fishing day, but not every day is a catching day.
translation.creole: Ebery day fishin' day, but ebery day no ketchin' day

translation.en: Every day you challenge your fellow, one day you will get your poison.
translation.creole: Ebery day you a-challenge you matty, wan day you sa get you' poison

translation.en: Every day you play in dirty water, one day it will dirty your skin.
translation.creole: Ebery day you a-play a-dutty watah, wan day he go nassy you' 'kin

translation.en: Every field must have grass.
translation.creole: Ebery fiel' mus' get grass

translation.en: Every fool has his own sense.
translation.creole: Ebery fool got he own sense

translation.en: Every grass is a man at night time.
translation.creole: Ebery grass is a man a-night time

translation.en: Not every haul of the net catches June fish.
translation.creole: Ebery haul ob de net no ketch June fish

translation.en: Not every greeting is a genuine greeting.
translation.creole: Ebery howdee na howdee

translation.en: Every vulture thinks its own offspring is white.
translation.creole: Ebery John crow t'ink he own picknie white

translation.en: Not every smile is genuine.
translation.creole: Ebery 'kin teet' no laugh

translation.en: Every long prayer must have an amen.
translation.creole: Ebery lang prayer mus' gat amen

translation.en: Every lawyer likes a fat fowl.
translation.creole: Ebery lawyer like fat fowl

translation.en: Every man knows where his own house is leaking.
translation.creole: Ebery man know weh he own house a-leak

translation.en: Every man is master of his own house.
translation.creole: Ebery man massa fo' he own house

translation.en: Every man to his own class
translation.creole: Ebery man to he own class

translation.en: Every man works for money, but not every man can keep it.
translation.creole: Ebery man wo'k fo' money, but no ebery man can keep am

translation.en: Every made up face doesn't cry.
translation.creole: Ebery mek up face na cry

translation.en: Every rope has two ends.
translation.creole: Ebery rope gat two en'

translation.en: Not every handshake is a genuine handshake.
translation.creole: Ebery shake han' no shake han'

translation.en: Not everyone who has their eyes closed is asleep.
translation.creole: Ebery shut eye na a-sleep

translation.en: Every sore eye is a watery eye, but not every watery eye is a sore eye.
translation.creole: Eberysore yeye a watah yeye, but na ebery watah yeye a sore yeye

translation.en: Every thief knows his own trade.
translation.creole: Ebery tief man know he own trade

translation.en: Every time a chicken drinks water, it lifts its head up and says "Thank God".
translation.creole: Ebery time fowl drink watah, he hise he head a-tap an'say "Teng Gaad

translation.en: Every time it rains, the carrion crow swears he will build a house; when the sun comes out, he forgets.
translation.creole: Ebery time rain fall clarinclo swear he sa buil' house; when sun come out, he fo'get

translation.en: Every tub stands on its own bottom.
translation.creole: Ebery tub'tan' pon he own battam

translation.en: Every water is for drinking, but not every story is for telling.
translation.creole: Ebery watah fo' drink, but ebery 'tory no fo' tell

translation.en: Everywhere you turn, a close friend is there.
translation.creole: Ebery way you tu'n primo matty deh

translation.en: Not every wind is suitable for full sail.
translation.creole: Ebery win' na a-full sail

translation.en: The elephant knows that its backbone is big, that's why it tries to swallow a coconut.
translation.creole: Elephant sabby say be back-bone big da mek so he look fo' swalla coc'nut

translation.en: The elephant says, despite his size, he doesn't want trouble with man.
translation.creole: Elephant say wid all he big, he no wan' 'tory wid man

translation.en: An elephant's ears are big, but it doesn't hear its own story.
translation.creole: Elephant yase big, but he no a-yeddy he own 'tory

translation.en: An empty bag can't stand up.
translation.creole: Empty bag can't 'tan' up

translation.en: He can see his neighbor's faults, but can't see his own.
translation.creole: Eye can see he matty, but can't see hese'f

translation.en: Hard times make a man boil calalu (This means that difficult circumstances can force a person to make do with whatever they have, in this case, preparing a simple dish like calalu.)
translation.creole: Ha'd time mek man bile calalu

translation.en: Hard times make a poor man eat matty.
translation.creole: Ha'd time mek poo' man eat matty

translation.en: Hard times make a smoker smoke tobacco stick.
translation.creole: Ha'd time mek smoke man smoke tabacca 'tick

translation.en: It's hard to get butter out of a dog's throat.
translation.creole: Ha'd to get buttah out ob a daag t'roat

translation.en: Hair doesn't know what's in the head.
translation.creole: Hair na know wha' deh a-head

translation.en: A small problem creates a big issue that money can't solve.
translation.creole: Half-a-bitt mek trouble joe can't cure

translation.en: If your hand is in a tiger's mouth, you must pull it out very carefully.
translation.creole: Han' deh a-tigah mout', you mus' pull out safly safly

translation.en: A handful has company.
translation.creole: Han'-full hab company

translation.en: Give and take
translation.creole: Han' go, han' come

translation.en: Hands make rope, rope ties hands.
translation.creole: Han' mek rope, rope tie han'

translation.en: A girl with a handsome face is not necessarily the best kind of girl.
translation.creole: Han'some face gal na de besses kin' a gal

translation.en: When hands wash each other, both hands become clean.
translation.creole: Han' was' han' all too han' clean

translation.en: A harness doesn't fit a dog and a cat.
translation.creole: Harness no a-fit daag an' cat

translation.en: He carries his fortune on his back.
translation.creole: He a-carry he fortune on he back

translation.en: He keeps his book so well that even a cockroach can't get it.
translation.creole: He a-keep book so da cockroach se'f can't get am

translation.en: Heavy clouds, no rain
translation.creole: Heavy clould, no rain

translation.en: He went through the woods and picked up a crooked stick.
translation.creole: He bin t'rough the woods, an' he pick up a crooked 'tick

translation.en: He blows hot and cold with the same mouth.
translation.creole: He blow hot an' col' wid de same mout'

translation.en: He has the key to the street.
translation.creole: He gat de key a de street

translation.en: He already has a sheep's head.
translation.creole: He gat sheep head a-ready

translation.en: He is like a ship without a bottom.
translation.creole: He like a ship widout a battam

translation.en: His mouth is as sweet as a pot full of rice.
translation.creole: He mout' sweet like a rice-full pat

translation.en: He is not at the water container.
translation.creole: He na deh a-gooby

translation.en: Hang your basket where your hand can reach it.
translation.creole: Heng you' quake weh you' han' can meet am

translation.en: He picked my teeth to get to my gums.
translation.creole: He pick a-me teet' fo' get a-me gums

translation.en: The herring came to ask the pickle how it's doing.
translation.creole: Herrin' come fo' ask pickle how he situate

translation.en: His tongue doesn't have a bone, it's like a clock.
translation.creole: He tongue na gat leb na clock

translation.en: Secure the cow before you negotiate to sell the beef.
translation.creole: Hol' de cow befo' you bargain fo' sell de beef

translation.en: The cat got burnt by hot water, now it's scared even of cold water.
translation.creole: Hot watah bu'n cat, when he see col' watah he friken

translation.en: Houri told Patwa one day we will meet at the stop-off.
translation.creole: Houri tell patwa wan day awe sa meet a-'tap off

translation.en: Greetings and thanks break no bones
translation.creole: Howdee an' tenkee break no bones

translation.en: A hundred dollars is in a house, nobody hears; but when death occurs, there's too much crying.
translation.creole: Hundred dallah get in a house, nobody no yeddy; but dead get in, too much cry

translation.en: Hunger makes a man's mouth corner white.
translation.creole: Hungry belly mek man mout' ca'nah white

translation.en: A hungry man doesn't know that soup is sweet.
translation.creole: Hungry belly man na know soup na sweet

translation.en: Hunger tells a sweet mouth to "stand aside".
