translation.creole: Hungry belly tell sweet mout' " 'Tan' wan side

translation.en: Hunger drove the Chinese man, he ate a snake.
translation.creole: Hungry bode (take hold of) Chinee, he nyam snake

translation.en: Hunger has no master.
translation.creole: Hungry gat no massa

translation.en: A hungry man looks for something to eat, even if it's just salt; a satisfied man finds fault.
translation.creole: Hungry man look fo' nyam salt ; man satisfy, he fin' fault

translation.en: Hunger makes a man thin.
translation.creole: Hungry mek man magah

translation.en: If you're not hungry, don't curse the thief.
translation.creole: Hungry no bode you, no cuss tief man

translation.en: Rushing leads to poor results.
translation.creole: Hurry hurry mek bad curry

translation.en: If an alligator comes out of the water's bottom and tells you, "The water mamma is blind," you must believe it.
translation.creole: If alligittah come out a-watah battam tell you say, "Watah mamma yeye blin'," you mus' belieb am

translation.en: If I tell you last year's story, you'll have tears in your eyes.
translation.creole: If a tell you las' yeah 'tory, watah run a-you yeye

translation.en: If a bad reputation could kill a rat, all rats would be dead.
translation.creole: If bad name could kill rat, all ratta go dead

translation.en: If a coal pot doesn't have a bottom, fire can't stand.
translation.creole: If coal pat na gat battam, fiah can't 'tan'

translation.en: If the chicken coop is full, a chicken can't make rat eggs hatch.
translation.creole: If fowl house full, fowl can't mek ratten eggs hatch

translation.en: If the greedy person waits, the soup will cool.
translation.creole: If greedy wait, hot sa cool

translation.en: If he had a spoon, he would drink soup.
translation.creole: If he bin hab spoon, he sa drink soup

translation.en: If he had spat him out, he couldn't resemble him more.
translation.creole: If he bin spit he out, he couldn't favah he mo'

translation.en: If a donkey could talk, it would say "Oh, poor Job!"
translation.creole: If jackass could a-talk he sa say "Aow, poo' Job!

translation.en: If a man is idle, he tempts the devil.
translation.creole: If man am idle, he temp' de debil

translation.en: If a man milks a cow, he must drink milk.
translation.creole: If man milk cow, he mus' drink milk

translation.en: If a man doesn't bend his back, he will hit his head on a post.
translation.creole: If man na ben' he back, he go jam he head a-post

translation.en: If a man sits up high and he falls, he will break his neck.
translation.creole: If man si' down high an' he fall, he go bruck he neck

translation.en: If I had known, it's always behind the door.
translation.creole: If me bin know always deh behin' de doo

translation.en: If I had known it would have bad consequences
translation.creole: If me bin know is a bad after-blow

translation.en: If I had known, I would have lost my child for its mother.
translation.creole: If me bin know, me loss picknie fo' mamma

translation.en: If my man doesn't beat me, he doesn't love me.
translation.creole: If me man no beat me, he no lobe me

translation.en: If a child doesn't hear "Stop," they won't hear "Be careful."
translation.creole: If picknie no heah "Done," he no heah "Tek ca'

translation.en: If a snake bites you and you see a lizard, you must run.
translation.creole: If snake bite you an' you see lizar', you mus' run

translation.en: If the sun hasn't set, a man hasn't finished crying.
translation.creole: If sun no done, man no done cry

translation.en: If a stranger heard what his walking stick said, he would never go to a strange man's house.
translation.creole: If 'tranjah man bin heah wha' he walkin'-'tick say, he nebba go a-'trange man house

translation.en: If trousers say the master is a thief, you can't doubt it.
translation.creole: If trouses say massa tief, you can't paca (doubt.)

translation.en: If the eye doesn't see, the mouth can't talk.
translation.creole: If yeye no see, mout' can't talk

translation.en: If you blow fire with your mouth, ashes will go in your eyes.
translation.creole: If you blow fiah wid you mout', ashes sa go a-you yeye

translation.en: If you can't get turkey, you must be satisfied with John Crow (a vulture or undesirable option).
translation.creole: If you can't get tu'key, you mus' satisfy wid John Crow

translation.en: If you're greedy for your friend's stew, you'll end up buying bread for the cat with the smell.
translation.creole: If you craben fo' you matty chue (stew), you sa buy bread fo' cat wid de scent

translation.en: If you insult the John Crow by calling it "bald head," the guinea hen gets angry.
translation.creole: If you cuss John Crow "Peel head," guinea hen bex

translation.en: If you eat labba (a small wild animal) and drink creek water, you won't be able to leave the country.
translation.creole: If you eat labba an' drink creek watah, you no able fo lef' de country

translation.en: If your finger gets sore, don't cut it off and throw it away.
translation.creole: If you fingah get sore, na cut am t'row 'way

translation.en: If you follow the spring tide, you will be left at the dam.
translation.creole: If you fallow spring tide, you sa lef' a-dam

translation.en: If you go to a new place, don't curse where you came from.
translation.creole: If you go a-new place, na cuss weh you come out

translation.en: If you're handsome, there's trouble; if you're ugly, there's trouble.
translation.creole: If you han'some da trouble, if you hugly da trouble

translation.en: If you rush, your soup will be salty.
translation.creole: If you hurry, you' soup salt

translation.en: If you like the dog, you must like its tail.
translation.creole: If you like dang, you mus' like 'e tail

translation.en: If you don't blow your own trumpet, your neighbor won't blow it for you.
translation.creole: If you no blow you' own trumpet, you' matty no go blow am fo' you

translation.en: If you don't come back before the spit dries, I'll know you've been playing.
translation.creole: If you no come back befo' spit dry, me know you bin a-play

translation.en: If you don't know the story, ask Jim Crow what happened to John Crow at the high dam pasture.
translation.creole: If you no know 'tory, ask Jim Crow wha' happen John Crow a-high dam pastah

translation.en: If you don't live in a house, you don't know where it leaks.
translation.creole: If you no libe a-house, you no know weh he a-leak

translation.en: If you don't interfere with the witch doctor, the witch doctor will never finish you for money.
translation.creole: If you no meddle wid obeahman, obeahman nebba dun you fo' money

translation.en: If your right eye twitches, you will meet something good, if your left eye twitches, you will encounter something bad.
translation.creole: If you' right eye dance you sa meet good, if you' lef' eye dance you sa meet bad

translation.en: If you think I'm a fool, put your hand to my mouth.
translation.creole: If you t'ink me a fool, put you' han' a-me mout'

translation.en: If you want a white person to be pleased (lick his lips), give him plantain water in a calabash.
translation.creole: If you wan' Bacra lickrish (lick his lips) gie am plantain watah a-calabash

translation.en: If you want to eat toad, eat it with egg.
translation.creole: If you wan' fo' eat crapaud, eat am wid egg

translation.en: If you want to know the story, take a walk abroad.
translation.creole: If you wan' no 'tory, tek you' walk abroad

translation.en: If you want to see a monkey cry, stick pepper in its eye.
translation.creole: If you wan' see monkey cry, 'tick peppah in he eye

translation.en: If there's no wick, the lamp can't burn.
translation.creole: If wick na deh, lamp can't bu'n

translation.en: If the wind doesn't blow, the leaf doesn't shake.
translation.creole: If win' no blow, leaf no shake

translation.en: If the wind doesn't blow, you won't see the chicken's backside.
translation.creole: If win no blow, you no see fowl back

translation.en: If you act hastily, you will regret it.
translation.creole: If you yeye jump, you a-go cry

translation.en: I am a saucepan without a cover.
translation.creole: I is saucepan widout a cubbah

translation.en: It's a calabash whip for hitting the witch doctor with.
translation.creole: Is calabash whip fo' lick obeahman wid

translation.en: It's the answer that causes the argument.
translation.creole: Is de ansah does bring de row

translation.en: The luck of a lousy cat is astonishing.
translation.creole: Is de luck ob a lousy cat does 'tonish

translation.en: You shouldn't be afraid of a dog that's not barking at you.
translation.creole: Is no daag wah a-bark you mus' friken

translation.en: It's what comes out of your mouth that causes trouble, not what's in your belly.
translation.creole: Is wha' come out a-you' mout dá mek trouble, na wha' deh a-you belly

translation.en: There's no situation so bad that it can't improve.
translation.creole: It is a bad tide which cannot turn

translation.en: It takes a very smart man to catch a hare.
translation.creole: It tek very smart man fo ketch accouri

translation.en: The donkey is in the bush, but the governor is in the house.
translation.creole: Jackass a-bush, but gubnah a-house

translation.en: The donkey drinks rum, but the hog gets drunk.
translation.creole: Jackass drink rum, haag get drunk

translation.en: If a bull is loose in the pasture, a person is not obliged to walk near it.
translation.creole: Bull loose a-pasture, man no bound fo' walk close am

translation.en: The bull is old, he smeared his tail.
translation.creole: Bull ol,' he smear he tail

translation.en: The bush is burning behind the tiger, and the tiger doesn't smell the smoke.
translation.creole: Bush bu'n behin' tigah, an' tigah no smell smoke

translation.en: The bush has ears
translation.creole: Bush gat yase

translation.en: Buy your food, eat according to your money.
translation.creole: Buy you' nyam, nyam accordin' to you money

translation.en: Ugly chickens eat good corn.
translation.creole: Caba ca-ba fowl nyam good co'n

translation.en: A calabash can float in a trench, but it can't float in a river.
translation.creole: Calabash a-float a-trench, but can't float a-ribah,

translation.en: A calabash is a poor man's finger basin.
translation.creole: Calabash a poo-man fingah basin

translation.en: The outside of a calabash is green, but its inside is white.
translation.creole: Calabash outside green, but he belly white

translation.en: A boa constrictor looks good if there are ants before it lies down.
translation.creole: Camoodi does look good if ants deh befo' he lie down

translation.en: You can't destroy Penitence to make Ruimveldt good.
translation.creole: Can't bruck Penitent fo' mek Rumfelt good

translation.en: "Can't help" is not done on purpose.
translation.creole: Can't help" no do fo' purpose

translation.en: Can't fatten a cow for another butcher
translation.creole: Can't fatten cow fo' nadda butcher

translation.en: Can't stop the river from running.
translation.creole: Can't tap de ribah from runnin'

translation.en: You can't use your bare eyes to roast my corn.
translation.creole: Can't tek you dry eye fo' roas' me co'n

translation.en: The captain of a man-of-war became a cook on a Guinea ship.
translation.creole: Cap'n a-man-o-war tu'n cook a-Guinea ship

translation.en: Captain Trust has died, bad pay killed him.
translation.creole: Cap'n Trus' gone dead, bad pay a-kill am

translation.en: Captain Trust has gone home.
translation.creole: Cap'n Trus' gone home

translation.en: The carrion crow eats the cow, but the cow can't eat the carrion crow.
translation.creole: Carrin crow a-nyam cow, cow can't nyam carrin crow

translation.en: The carrion crow says, "The mercy of the Lord is not on a tree."
translation.creole: Carrin crow say, "De mercy ob de Laad no deh 'pon tree

translation.en: The carrion crow says, "There is one God above, he never eats grass."
translation.creole: Carrin crow say, "Wan Gaad deh a-tap, he nebbah nyam grass

translation.en: Carrow follows the carrion crow, he sleeps by the fire side.
translation.creole: Carrow falla carrincrow, he sleep a-fiah side

translation.en: Cassava and okra can't make a good soup.
translation.creole: Cassada an' ochro can't mek good soup

translation.en: If the cassava is not ripe, do not scratch its bottom.
translation.creole: Cassada no ripe, no 'cratch he battam

translation.en: The cat is chasing the rat, but it's stealing its master's pork.
translation.creole: Cat a-dribe rat, but he tief he massa po'k

translation.en: When a cat plays with a bone, the dog wants it.
translation.creole: Cat a-play wid bone, daag want am

translation.en: A cat's paw is soft, but it can scratch indeed.
translation.creole: Cat foot saf', but he 'cratch fo' true

translation.en: When the cat's away, the rat takes over.
translation.creole: Cat no deh, ratta tek over

translation.en: "Deceitful lives a handful do."
translation.creole: 'Ceitful lib a-han'-fu11 doo'

translation.en: Chance can knock down even the devil himself.
translation.creole: Chance blow knack down de debil se'f

translation.en: Exchange for exchange
translation.creole: Changee fo' changee

translation.en: Talk to her, boy, you can win her over.
translation.creole: Chat am, boy, you sa win am

translation.en: Cheap things make everyone buy.
translation.creole: Cheap t'ing mek all man buy

translation.en: The chicken-hawk says, if he can't get the mother, he'll take the child.
translation.creole: Chicken-hawk say, he can't get mamma, he tek picknie

translation.en: The chicken-hawk says, he lives by his skill; the carrion-crow, by the grace of God.
translation.creole: Chicken-hawk say, he lib by he skill; carrin-crow, by de grace ob God

translation.en: A chicken hawk never builds its nest with a ground dove.
translation.creole: Chicken hawk nebba buil' he nes' wid ground dove

translation.en: The foolish hawk bought his rum, the goat drank it, but the sheep got drunk.
translation.creole: Chupit haag buy he rum, goat drink am, but sheep get drunk

translation.en: The foolish man gave away his spoon and ate with his hand.
translation.creole: Chupit man gie 'way he 'poon, an' eat wid 'e han.'

translation.en: A foolish man will close his neighbor's sluice, and leave his own open.
translation.creole: Chupit man go shut he matty kokah, an' lef' he own open

translation.en: A foolish man lets the water carry away his food twice.
translation.creole: Chupit man mek watah car''way he lap two time

translation.en: The foolish man melts lead in a sardine can.
translation.creole: Chupit man melt lead a-sardine pat

translation.en: A foolish man raced against a horse.
translation.creole: Chupit man run race wid hass

translation.en: A foolish man works and saves his money; when he dies, a wise man spends it.
translation.creole: Chupit man wo'k, put he money; when he dead, sense man spen' am

translation.en: A foolish man wrote it, a wise man can't read it.
translation.creole: Chupit man write am, sense man can't read am

translation.en: The carrion crow governor told the dog to show himself.
translation.creole: Claninclo a-gubnah tell daag show hese'f

translation.en: Cloth is easy to get dirty, but hard to wash.
translation.creole: Clat' easy fo' dutty, but haad fo' was'

translation.en: The rooster crows at the door, it's a sign that a stranger is coming.
translation.creole: Cock crow a-doo' mout', a sign 'tranger a-come

translation.en: The rooster scrambles, the hen scrambles, the children scramble, they can't sleep hungry.
translation.creole: Cock grabble, hen grabble, picknie grabble, dem can't sleep hungry

translation.en: The cockroach is always so drunk, it never walks into the chicken's house.
translation.creole: Cockroach ebba so drunk, he no walk a-fowl house

translation.en: The cockroach said it had feet to run, but the centipede caught it.
translation.creole: Cockroach say he gat foot fo' run, but sentapee catch am

translation.en: A coconut tree branch never fights a strong wind.
translation.creole: Coc'nut tree branch nebba fight high win'

translation.en: "Come, come," is a sweet, fish.
translation.creole: Come, come," is a sweet, fish

translation.en: There's more corn flour than water.
translation.creole: Co'n flour mo' dan watah

translation.en: The Congo eel is still considered a fish.
translation.creole: Congo eel still is a fish

translation.en: Congo mulatto, who is going to marry you?
translation.creole: Congo mulatto, who sa marry you?

translation.en: Congo sir lives a handful door.
translation.creole: Congo sah lib a-han'-full doo

translation.en: Consequences are why the crab has no head.
translation.creole: Consequential mek crab hab no head

translation.en: A contented man eats pepper and salt for breakfast.
translation.creole: Contented man eat peppah an' sal' fo' breakfast

translation.en: If the thick porridge doesn't choke you, don't drink the okra soup.
translation.creole: Coo-coo no choke you no drink ochro soup

translation.en: The laborer has a clean dam for washing, he sits down and says he is truly grieving.
translation.creole: Coolie gat clean dam fo' dutty, he si' down say he a-prap sorrow

translation.en: The Indian man wears a loincloth, it's no wonder, it's the fashion in his country.
translation.creole: Coolie wear baba, na wandah, da he country fashion

translation.en: The Cottee-cotte soup has all its steam at the bottom.
translation.creole: Cottee-cotte-soup hab all he 'team a-battam

translation.en: Country destroys country
translation.creole: Country kill country

translation.en: The country has changed, but my heart hasn't changed.
translation.creole: Country tu'n, but me haat no tu'n

translation.en: A cowardly man keeps all his bones intact.
translation.creole: Coward man keep whole bone

translation.en: When the cow dies, it leaves its skin as a story.
translation.creole: Cow dead, he lef' 'tory gie he 'kin

translation.en: When the cow dies, its owner cries; the carrion crow laughs.
translation.creole: Cow dead, he massa cry; carrin crow laugh

translation.en: The cow is in the pasture, it doesn't remember the butcher and the dog until it sees them.
translation.creole: Cow deh a-pastah, he no membah butchah an' daag teh he see am

translation.en: The cow never says "Goodbye" to the pasture.
translation.creole: Cow nebbah tell pastah "Goo' bye

translation.en: The cow doesn't eat pepper, but it fertilizes it.
translation.creole: Cow no eat peppah, but he down a-manure am

translation.en: If a cow doesn't have a tail, God Almighty will swat the flies.
translation.creole: Cow no hab tail, Gaad A'mighty brush fly

translation.en: The cow doesn't realize its loss until the fly season.
translation.creole: Cow no know he loss 'e tail teh cow-fly season

translation.en: The cow says it's dirty because of the dam, but it's actually dirty because of its own tail.
translation.creole: Cow say he dutty 'pon dam, but he dutty he own tail

translation.en: A cow's tail never surpasses its head.
translation.creole: Cow tail nebba pass he head

translation.en: A greedy dog loses both the corn and its husk.
translation.creole: Craben daag a-loss co'n an' husk

translation.en: The crab knows its hole, but the toad doesn't know its hole.
translation.creole: Crab know he 'ole, but crapaud na know he 'ole

translation.en: If a crab doesn't move, it doesn't get fat; if it moves too much, it gets hit.
translation.creole: Crab no walk he no get fat; he walk too much, he get a-pat

translation.en: Scrape your own calabash, before you scrape your neighbor's own.
translation.creole: 'Crape you own calabash, befo' you 'crape you matty own

translation.en: The frog didn't know the water was hot until it fell on its back.
translation.creole: Crapaud no bin sabby too watah teh hot watah fall a-he back

translation.en: A crazy man knows who the governor is.
translation.creole: Crazy man know gubnah

translation.en: The crow is always ready for a funeral, that's why it wears its burial suit.
translation.creole: Crow always ready fo' funeral mek he wear he berrin' suit

translation.en: A child who cries all the time will never get their way.
translation.creole: Cry-cry picknie nehba hab right

translation.en: Cuffy! Come see fish in the muddy water.
translation.creole: Cuffy! come see fish a-muddy watah

translation.en: Arguments never left a mark on my skin.
translation.creole: Cuss-cuss nebba bore hole a-me 'kin

translation.en: Cut off a cow's horn, you don't cut its heart.
translation.creole: Cut cow handle, you no cut he haat

translation.en: Envy doesn't kill a dog.
translation.creole: Cut yeye na a-kill daag

translation.en: The dog bites his friend, but he doesn't bite himself.
translation.creole: Daag a-bite he matty, but he no a-bite hese'f

translation.en: The dog is biting its tail, but it's not barking at itself.
translation.creole: Daag a-bite he tail, but he na a-bark 'pon hese'f

translation.en: The dog bites the master, but the master doesn't bite the dog.
translation.creole: Daag a-bite massa, but massa na a-bite daag

translation.en: The dog always lies down where the bone is being stirred.
translation.creole: Daag always lie down da place bone a-'tir

translation.en: Dog and cat can't eat from the same plate.
translation.creole: Dang an' cat can't eat a-wan plate

translation.en: The dog is running for its character, the hog is running for its life.
translation.creole: Daag a-run fo' he charatah, haag a-run fo' he life

translation.en: When the dog is present, it's "Mr. Dog"; when the dog is not present, it's just "Dog".
translation.creole: Daag deh, "Mr. Daag"; daag no deh, no mo' "Daag

translation.en: The dog drinks water noisily for itself, but not for us.
translation.creole: Daag drink watah chakoo chakoo fi you a-fi you, but fi awe no fi you

translation.en: "A dog with a broken foot knows the mouth of its master's door."
translation.creole: Daag foot-bruck, he know he massa doo' mout.'

translation.en: The dog has money to buy butter to roast on the fire.
translation.creole: Daag gat money buy buttah roas' a-fiah

translation.en: If a dog had money, he would buy cheese.
translation.creole: Daag gat money, he buy cheese

translation.en: A dog has four feet, but can't walk four roads at once.
translation.creole: Daag hab four foot, but can't walk four road wan time

translation.en: If a dog has too many masters, it will starve.
translation.creole: Daag hab too much massa him 'tarve

translation.en: The dog lapped water saying "What's yours is yours."
translation.creole: Daag lap watah say " Fo' you da fo' you

translation.en: What's happening, look out quickly before it passes.
translation.creole: Wha' a-pass, look out quick befo' he pass

translation.en: What comes from the devil's back goes under his belly.
translation.creole: Wha' come from de debil back go undah he belly

translation.en: What comes out of your stomach won't go into mine.
translation.creole: Wha' come out a-you belly no a-go in a-me own

translation.en: What comes out must go in.
translation.creole: Wha' come out sa go in

translation.en: What is the house in front of you, what is the bush for us.
translation.creole: Wha' da-house a-fo' you, wha' da-bush a-f' awe

translation.en: What's on the ground is for the dog, but not all dogs will pick it up.
translation.creole: Wha' deh a-groun' fo' daag, but no all daag a-pick am

translation.en: What's in the stick's head, is in the snake's head.
translation.creole: Wah' deh a stick head, deh a-snake head

translation.en: What's in your stomach doesn't need to come out of your mouth.
translation.creole: Wha' deh a-you belly na mek am pass t'rough you' mout'

translation.en: What's in the old goat must be in the kid.
translation.creole: Wha' deh in de ol' goat mus' be in de picknie

translation.en: What falls in the fire, you will find it in the ashes.
translation.creole: Wha' fall a-fiah you sa fin' am a-ashes

translation.en: What falls from the head goes to the shoulder.
translation.creole: Wha' fall from head go a-shouldah

translation.en: What was the fly doing before the cow got a sore eye?
translation.creole: Wha' fly bin a-do befo' cow get sore yeye?

translation.en: What can a fly do with a turtle's back?
translation.creole: Wha' fly can do wid tu'tle' back?

translation.en: What happens to the black fowl will happen to the white fowl.
translation.creole: Wha' happen to black fowl sa happen to white fowl

translation.en: What hurts the eye makes the nose run water.
translation.creole: Wha' hu't yeye mek nose run watah

translation.en: What was the Mahaica man doing before Munro's horse died of glanders?
translation.creole: Wha' Mahaica niggah bin a-do befo' Munro glandas haas dead?

translation.en: What motion quicksilver has at the bottom, it doesn't have at the top.
translation.creole: Wha' motion quicksilver got a-battam, he na gat a-sluice

translation.en: What's not good for breakfast is not good for dinner.
translation.creole: Wha' no good fo' breakfas' no good fo' dinnah

translation.en: What has passed, let it go; what is to come, sit down and wait for it.
translation.creole: Wha' pass chase am let 'e go, wha' a-come si down wait am

translation.en: What sense is in a snake's head, the same is in a stick's head.
translation.creole: Wha' sense deb a-snake head, de same deh a-bostick-head

translation.en: What does the term "tocle" have to do with a cow-fly?
translation.creole: Wha' some'ting tocle sa do wid cow-fly?

translation.en: What the eye doesn't see, the heart doesn't burn for.
translation.creole: Wha' yeye no see haat no bu'n

translation.en: What the ears don't hear, the heart doesn't burn over.
translation.creole: Wha' ears no heah haat no bu'n

translation.en: What your eyes don't see, your mouth doesn't water for.
translation.creole: Wha' you' eye no see you mout' no run watah

translation.en: What you gain in one area, you lose in another.
translation.creole: Wha' you gain in jigging you lose in shuffling

translation.en: What you put in the pickle never spoils.
translation.creole: Wha' you put in de pickle nebbah 'pile

translation.en: What's too heavy for your hand, roll it on the ground.
translation.creole: Wha' too heaby fo' you han' roll am a-groun'

translation.en: What you lost in the saucepan, you must find in the bottom of the coal pot.
translation.creole: Wha' you loss a-saucepan you mus' fin' a-bottom coal pot

translation.en: When an aboriginal Indian wants to harm you, he says "Fair play, no pilfering".
translation.creole: When Buck wan' a-damage you he say "Fair play no pra pra

translation.en: When a building catches fire, the master begs the laborer for help.
translation.creole: When buil'in' a-ketch fiah massa beg labrah

translation.en: When two bulls meet, they call each other "Brother".
translation.creole: When bull an' bull meet dey call matty "Bro

translation.en: When two bulls are in conversation, the steer has no business there.
translation.creole: When bull an' bull a-chat, capoon na gat business deh

translation.en: When cassava and okra meet in the pot, the pot must burn.
translation.creole: When cassada an' ochro meet a-pat, pat mus' bu'n

translation.en: When the cat's belly is full, it says "The rat stinks".
translation.creole: When cat belly full, he say "Ratta 'tink

translation.en: When a cat can't get milk, it remembers there are birds in the bush.
translation.creole: When cat na get milk, he 'membah bi'd a-bush

translation.en: When the carrion crow gets an itch in its eye, it thinks it's a governor.
translation.creole: When claninclo get yeye-tickle he t'ink hese'f gubnah

translation.en: When the carrion crow has eaten its fill, it flaps its wings at its neighbor.
translation.creole: When claninclo nyam belly-full, he shake 'e wing 'pon 'e matty

translation.en: When a chigger is in your foot, it's as tough as being pricked with a cattan.
translation.creole: When chiggah foot a rattan 'tuff am wid cattan

translation.en: When a coconut falls from the tree, it can't be reattached.
translation.creole: When coc'nut fall from tree he can't fasten back

translation.en: When a cockroach hosts a dance, he doesn't invite the chicken.
translation.creole: When cockroach gie dance, he no hax fowl

translation.en: When a poor man gets money, he shakes the governor's hand.
translation.creole: When cocoby man get money, 'e shake gubnah han'

translation.en: When a tough man meets another tough man, he says "There's no time."
translation.creole: When cuffman meet cuffman he say "Time no deh

translation.en: When a dog gets hit, it tucks its tail under its belly and runs away, yelping for sure, but watch out when it comes back.
translation.creole: When daag get lick he put 'e tail under he belly an' run an' halla fo' true, but look sharp when he come back

translation.en: When pork is delicious, a person keeps it in their mouth for a long time.
translation.creole: When flesin po'k sweet, man a-keep am lang a-he mout'

translation.en: When one bird meets another in bird country, one tells the other "Just like that!"
translation.creole: When fowl an' fowl meet a-fowl country, tara tell tara "So by

translation.en: When the rooster gets drunk, he forgets that the black-handled knife is in the kitchen.
translation.creole: When fowl-cock get grog, he fo'get say "black 'andle knife deh a-kitchen

translation.en: When chickens have teeth and dogs eat razors.
translation.creole: When fowl get teet' an' daag nyam razah

translation.en: When the ibis sees fish, it forgets that there's a gun.
translation.creole: When galin see fish, he fo'get say "Gun deh

translation.en: When a goat wants to roll, it rolls without the wind blowing it.
translation.creole: When goat down wan' roll he roll widout win' blow am

translation.en: When there's no horse, a donkey takes first place.
translation.creole: When haas na deh, jackass mek fus' place

translation.en: When he is calling God's name, that's when he is lying.
translation.creole: When he a-call Gad name, á de time he lie

translation.en: When he is here, he is here, when he is not here, he is not here.
translation.creole: When he deh he deh, when he na deh he na deh

translation.en: When the herring is fat and cooking, not everyone gets to smell it.
translation.creole: When herrin' fat a-bu'n, na all man a-smell am

translation.en: When a coolie (a person of Indian descent) is hungry, he is happy to eat pork.
translation.creole: When hungry ketch coolie, he glad fo' eat po'k

translation.en: When a donkey kicks a man, the man shouldn't bother to kick it back.
translation.creole: When jackass kick man, man mus'n't baddah kick am back

translation.en: When a little boy puts on a big man's trousers, he must accept what he gets.
translation.creole: When li'l boy put on big man trouses, wha' he get he mus' take

translation.en: When a small dog has a big liver, it will die before its time.
translation.creole: When li'l daag gat big libah, he go dead befo' 'e time

translation.en: When a little child wants to run, give him a long rope.
translation.creole: When li'l niggah wan' run, gie am lang rope

translation.en: When a man is going to eat at a woman's house, he must let the woman eat first.
translation.creole: When man a-go eat a-wan ooman 'ouse, he mus' leh a ooman eat fus'

translation.en: When a man is about to jump a fence, he must look carefully before he jumps.
translation.creole: When man a-go jump fence, he must look good befo' he jump

translation.en: When a man is writing, do not touch his pen.
translation.creole: When man a-write, no touch he pen

translation.en: When a man buys butter, his friend dips his finger deep.
translation.creole: When man buy buttah, he matty chook he fingah deep

translation.en: When a man is living well, he calls God "Congah".
translation.creole: When man get good libin' he call God "Congah

translation.en: When a man makes himself sugar, his friends will surely suck it.
translation.creole: When man mek hese'f sugah, 'e matty suck am fo' true

translation.en: When a man doesn't have a match, he uses a fire-stick to light the lamp.
translation.creole: When man na gat match he tek fiah-'tick fo' light lamp

translation.en: When a man sucks cane, he throws its peel on the ground.
translation.creole: When man suck cane, 'e mash 'e pilin' a-groun.'

translation.en: When a man wants to beat a dog, he finds a stick quickly.
translation.creole: When man wan' fo' beat daag, he 'fin' 'tick quick

translation.en: When my foot itches me, it's a sign that I'm going to walk.
translation.creole: When me foot itch me, a sign me go walk

translation.en: When my left hand itches, money is coming.
translation.creole: When me lef' han' 'cratch me, money a-come

translation.en: When my eyes are dancing, it's a sign I'm going to cry.
translation.creole: When me yeye a-dance, a sign me go cry

translation.en: When one tooth hurts you, all the rest are upset.
translation.creole: When one toot' hu't you, all de res' bex

translation.en: When the patwa (a type of fish) sees bait, it forgets that there's a hook at the bottom.
translation.creole: When patwa see bait, 'e fo'get say "'Ook de a-battam

translation.en: When a puppy gets plenty of milk, it turns up its nose at salt soup.
translation.creole: When puppy get plenty milk, he mek up he face 'pon sal' soup

translation.en: When it's drizzling, the devil and his wife are fighting for a ham bone.
translation.creole: When rain a-drizzle, debil an' he wife a-fight fo' ham bone

translation.en: When it's raining and the sun is shining, the devil is beating his wife.
translation.creole: When rain fall an' sun shining, debil licking he wife

translation.en: When a rat sees a cat, it never laughs.
translation.creole: When rat see cat, 'e nebbah laugh

translation.en: When the saucepan loses its cover, everyone peeps inside.
translation.creole: When saucepan loss he cobah, all man a-peep inside

translation.en: When a wound can't heal, one must sit down and bear it.
translation.creole: When sore can't get bettah, man gat fo' si' down bear am

translation.en: When the tiger gets old, the dog barks at it.
translation.creole: When ti'gah get ol', daag ba'k aftah am

translation.en: When the tiger is not there, the monkey gives the ball.
translation.creole: When tigal na deh, monkey gie ball

translation.en: When the tiger is sick, the deer lends him money.
translation.creole: When tigah sick, deer dun am fo' money

translation.en: When trouble comes, it doesn't blow its shell.
translation.creole: When trouble come, he no blow 'e shell

translation.en: When a white person gets into trouble, even a monkey's trousers will fit him.
translation.creole: When trouble ketch Bacra, monkey breeches fit am

translation.en: When trouble catches a man, he stands up and staggers; When trouble catches a woman, she sits down and considers.
translation.creole: When trouble ketch man, he 'tan' up an' 'taggah; When trouble ketch ooman, him si-down an' considah

translation.en: When two big bottles are on the table, the little one has no business there.
translation.creole: When two big bottle deh a-table, little wan no bu'iness

translation.en: When the barrel doesn't have a hoop, it must break down.
translation.creole: When tub na got hoople, he mus' bruck down

translation.en: When two dogs are fighting, the cat stands to one side.
translation.creole: When two daag get quarrel, Tom cat 'tan wan side

translation.en: When your brother is in trouble, don't laugh at him.
translation.creole: When you bruddah soak, don' laugh he

translation.en: When you're dead, you don't know, and when you know, you're already dead.
translation.creole: When you' dead you no sabby, an' when you sabby, you dead done

translation.en: When you get a donkey to ride, ride it for real.
translation.creole: When you get jackass fo' ride, ride am fo' true

translation.en: When you go into the bush, don't take the same road to come back.
translation.creole: When you go a-bush, no walk same road come back

translation.en: When you go to the countryside where they dance with one foot, you should also dance with one foot.
translation.creole: When you go a-country weh dem a-dance wid one foot, dance wid one foot too

translation.en: When you visit a friend's house, leave your appetite behind.
translation.creole: When you go a-frien' house, lef' you' 'tomach behin'

translation.en: When you have money, doors open; when you don't have, they shut.
translation.creole: When you gat money, doo' open; when you no gat, he shut

translation.en: When you have the devil to deal with, feed him with a long spoon.
translation.creole: When you hab de debil fo' deal wid, feed am wid long 'poon

translation.en: When your hand is yellow, dogs will make it so.
translation.creole: When you' han' yalla, daag mek so

translation.en: When you kill a bush cow, be careful how you carry it to the canoe.
translation.creole: When you kill comma, min' how you carry am a-canoe

translation.en: When you leave a wake, don't say "Good night".
translation.creole: When you lef' wake house, no say "Goo' night

translation.en: When you step on a dog, put on your shoes.
translation.creole: When you mash daag, put on you' shoes

translation.en: When your own louse bites you, it really bites you.
translation.creole: When you own louse bite you, he bite you fo' true

translation.en: Someone who cries inside the house, and someone who cries outside the door, it's the same thing.
translation.creole: A body wah cry a-house, an'a body wah cry a-doo', a same t'ing

translation.en: A person who they don't want to roast, should not sit near the fire.
translation.creole: A body wah dem no wan' fo' roas', no fo' si' down carnah fiah

translation.en: The agouti knows its teeth are strong; that's why it eats palm nuts.
translation.creole: Accouri know he teet' 'trang; da mek he eat banga

translation.en: The colony hare uses the alligator's teeth to make sugar cake.
translation.creole: Accouri tek cayman teet' he mek sugah cake

translation.en: I came to milk the cow, not to count the cattle.
translation.creole: A come fo' milk cow, no fo' reckon cattle

translation.en: A cow that cries for water doesn't really need it.
translation.creole: A cow wah cry fo' watah na he a-want am

translation.en: A dog has the liberty to watch the governor.
translation.creole: A daag hab libaty fo' watch a-de gubnah

translation.en: A dog's mouth prevents it from climbing a tree.
translation.creole: A daag mout' mek he can't climb tree

translation.en: After night, morning comes.
translation.creole: After night ma'nin' come

translation.en: Gold is causing the white man to die with yellow fever today.
translation.creole: A gold mek Bacra a dead wid yalla febah t'day

translation.en: A good friend is better than money in the pocket.
translation.creole: A good frien' is bettah dan money in de pocket

translation.en: It's hard to pay for music when you can't hear the banjo play.
translation.creole: A hard t'ing fo' pay fo' music when you no heah banja play

translation.en: A horse, with a good heart, allows a man to ride it as he likes.
translation.creole: A hass, good heart mek man a-ride am as he like

translation.en: A hint to Beniba makes Quashiba take notice.
translation.creole: A hint to Beniba mek Quashiba tek notice

translation.en: A little is better than nothing.
translation.creole: A little is bettah dan not'in.'

translation.en: All birds can sing, but not all birds can talk.
translation.creole: All bi'd can sing, but a11 bi'd can't talk

translation.en: All carrion crows eat dead meat, but not all dogs eat it.
translation.creole: All carrin crow a-nyam dead meat, but all dag na a-nyam am

translation.en: All cassava have the same skin, but they don't all taste the same way.
translation.creole: All cassada got same 'kin, but all na tas'e same way

translation.en: All cows are crying, but not all cows are butting.
translation.creole: All cow a-cry, but na all cow a-butt

translation.en: All dogs can bark, but some are scared to bite.
translation.creole: All daag can bark, but some frighten fo' bite

translation.en: Everyone can talk, but not everyone can listen.
translation.creole: All fool can talk, but na all can heah

translation.en: "Not all high beds are safe."
translation.creole: All high bed no saf.'

translation.en: Alligator and cayman, they're all the same thing.
translation.creole: Alligittah an' cayman, a11 same t'ing

translation.en: The alligator doesn't nurse its young, but they survive.
translation.creole: Alligittah no a-gie he picknie suck, but dem lib

translation.en: The alligator eats the frog to fill its belly, and the duck for its sweet taste.
translation.creole: Alligittah nyam crapaud fo'belly full, an' duck fo' sweet mout'

translation.en: The alligator saw a bird and thought it was a fish.
translation.creole: Alligittah see fowl, he say a fish

translation.en: All kinds of pleasure must have a stop-off.
translation.creole: All kin' ob plesha mus' get wan 'taff-aff

translation.en: Everyone can talk, but not everyone can act.
translation.creole: All man can talk, but na all can do

translation.en: All pork looks like meat, but not all are in season.
translation.creole: All po'k favah matty, but na all a-season

translation.en: Not all that is sweet is good, and not all that is bitter is bad.
translation.creole: All sweet na sweet, all bittah na bittah

translation.en: A man who doesn't know his own needs is a fool.
translation.creole: A man no know he own want is a fool

translation.en: An unlucky bird often gets an unlucky trap.
translation.creole: Anlucky bi'd often get anlucky trap

translation.en: Ants know when hard times are coming, that's why they carry plenty of food to store in their house.
translation.creole: Ants know hard time a-come, da mek he does carry plenty food fo' put a-he house

translation.en: Where there is water, that's where the blue fly lives.
translation.creole: A place fish watah deh, a de blue fly lib

translation.en: A place where a rat scrapes, you can see it from a distance, but where it stands up, you can't see it.
translation.creole: A place weh rat 'crape you a-see am fo' slice, weh he 'tan' up you no a-see am

translation.en: A pound of worry doesn't pay a gill of debt.
translation.creole: A pound ob fretment no pay a gill of debtment

translation.en: The same place where a thorn pricks your foot is the same place you must remove it from.
translation.creole: A same place pimplah chook you' foot, a same place you must take am out

translation.en: A spider had sense when the monkey went to kill it, it shouted that a gunman was coming.
translation.creole: A sense nancy bin got when monkey go fo' kill, he halla gun man a-come

translation.en: Where the ashes are cold, that's where the dog lies down.
translation.creole: Ashes col', daag lie down deh

translation.en: As his skin stands, so stands his heart.
translation.creole: As he 'kin 'tan', so 'tan' he heart

translation.en: As long as there are school teachers, what you don't know today, you will know tomorrow.
translation.creole: As long as school missy an' school massa deh, wha' you no know t'day you sa know to-morrow

translation.en: A tiger's size and intelligence is what allows it to live in the bush today.
translation.creole: A tigah bigness an' sense mek he lib a-bush to-day

translation.en: When the sun is setting, the hen doesn't gather her chicks, each one must fend for itself.
translation.creole: A time sun a-down fowl no a-grabble fo' he chicken, ya grabble fo' hese'f

translation.en: Watch your mouth, and I'll know what's going on inside your house.
translation.creole: A watch a-you' doo' mout', an' me know how you' house inside 'tan'

translation.en: We live in the bush.
translation.creole: Awe lib a-bush

translation.en: We two can't turn in the same pot.
translation.creole: Awe two coo-coo can't tu'n in de same pat

translation.en: When a baby is born, its feet are small.
translation.creole: Baby born, he foot small

translation.en: The back can wait, but not the stomach.
translation.creole: Back can wait, but no belly

translation.en: The white man saw the side-line dam before he walked a mile-long dam.
translation.creole: Bacra bin see side-line dam befo' he walk a mi'l-walk dam

translation.en: The white man is just like a cow's dung, he is dry on top, but wet at the bottom.
translation.creole: Bacra jus' like cow-down, he tap dry, he battam wet

translation.en: The white man is not a boy, the black man is not a fool.
translation.creole: Bacra no boy, niggah no fool

translation.en: If the white man doesn't speak, the black man won't understand.
translation.creole: Bacra no talk, niggah no sabby

translation.en: The white man stands like a doctor bird, he found sweet flowers on more than one tree.
translation.creole: Bacra 'tan' like dactah-bi'd, he fin sweet flower 'pon mo' 'an wan tree

translation.en: A bad cow gives a bucketful of milk and then kicks it over.
translation.creole: Bad cow gie bucketful milk an' kick am down

translation.en: No witchcraft can overcome a wicked heart.
translation.creole: Bad heart no obeah

translation.en: A bad musician makes noise with his foot.
translation.creole: Bad musicianer mek row wid he foot

translation.en: A bad reputation doesn't kill a rat.
translation.creole: Bad name no a-kill rat

translation.en: Trouble never has an owner
translation.creole: Bad nebbah gat ownah

translation.en: If the bag isn't full, it can't stand up.
translation.creole: Bag no full, he can't 'tan' up

translation.en: The baker never says his bread is sour.
translation.creole: Bakah nebhah Say 'e bread sour

translation.en: A deal is made before the country is taken.
translation.creole: Bargain mek befo' country tek

translation.en: The boat knows it doesn't have a keel, that's why it can't take a lot of sail.
translation.creole: Bateau know he na gat keel, da mek he can't tek plenty sail

translation.en: Battle without water is blowing "whoo-whoo" in the wind.
translation.creole: Battle berout watah a-blow "whoo-whoo" a-win'

translation.en: The battle is over, the water has run out.
translation.creole: Battle bore, watah run out

translation.en: The bat trusts himself, that's why he hangs from the rafters above.
translation.creole: Bat trus' hese'f mek he heng a-raftah tap

translation.en: If beef had no bones, dogs would have no business there.
translation.creole: Beef no ha' bone, daag no ha' no bu'iness deh

translation.en: In front of you, they act as if they're so innocent that not even butter would melt in their mouth, but behind your back, they're as harmful as a fire stick.
translation.creole: Befo' face like a buttah can't melt, behind back fiah 'tick

translation.en: Before farther, behind farther
translation.creole: Befo' farra, behin' farra

translation.en: Before marriage it's "my dear," after marriage it's "you brute."
translation.creole: Befo' wedding is "my dear," after wedding is "you brute.''

translation.en: A beggar is looking for work, but he is praying not to get it.
translation.creole: Beggah a-look fo' wo'k, but he a-pray fo' no get am

translation.en: A beggar begging from another beggar will never become rich.
translation.creole: Beggah beg from beggah nebbah grow rich

translation.en: Beg a man to work, but don't beg him to eat.
translation.creole: Beg man fo wo'k, but na beg am fo' eat

translation.en: Behind the back has no ears.
translation.creole: Behin' back no hab ear

translation.en: A man with a full belly tells a hungry man, "stay strong, buddy."
translation.creole: Belly-full man tell hungry man, "keep heart buddy

translation.en: A full belly breaks the pot.
translation.creole: Belly-full bruck pat

translation.en: Remember, if you spy on me, I will watch you too.
translation.creole: Bembah rubembah you peep me, me sa watch you

translation.en: It's better to watch a box full of cockroaches than a girl.
translation.creole: Bettah fo' watch wan ban'box full cockroach dan wan gal

translation.en: It's better to paddle your own canoe than to wait for your friend to paddle it for you.
translation.creole: Bettah paddle you' own canoe dan wait fo' you matty paddle am fo' you

translation.en: If a bird is angry with a tree, where will it perch?
translation.creole: Bi'd bex wid tree, weh he go 'tan' up?

translation.en: A bird that flies too high must pass its nest.
translation.creole: Bi'd fly too high mus' pass he nes'

translation.en: Big houses have big stories.
translation.creole: Big house ha' big 'tory

translation.en: The big river is overflowing its banks.
translation.creole: Big libah a-buss he belly

translation.en: A grown man doesn't run for no reason.
translation.creole: Big man no a-run fo' not'in'

translation.en: A big story overwhelms a dog.
translation.creole: Big 'tory choke daag

translation.en: The arrogant attitude choked the deceitful person.
translation.creole: Big yeye choke nancy cat

translation.en: Being ambitious made the man choose hard labor.
translation.creole: Big yeye mek niggah pick shovel 'tick

translation.en: Bill bird trusted himself to swallow a tooroo seed.
translation.creole: Bill bi'd trus' hese'f mek he swalla tooroo seed

translation.en: A black man as a master is the worst kind of master.
translation.creole: Black man massa de wossis kin' ob massa

translation.en: If a black man steals, he steals a small amount; if a white man steals, he steals an entire estate.
translation.creole: Black man tief, he tief half-a-bitt; bacra tief, he tief whole estate

translation.en: In a blind-eye country, a one-eyed man is governor.
translation.creole: Blin' yeye country, one yeye man a-gubnah

translation.en: A blind man can't carry news.
translation.creole: Blin' yeye man can't carry news

translation.en: A blind man knows his door's mouth.
translation.creole: Blin' yeye man know he doo' mout.'

translation.en: A blind man doesn't need a mirror.
translation.creole: Blin' yeye man na wan' lookin' glass

translation.en: A blind man never leaves his walking stick.
translation.creole: Blin' yeye man nebbah lef' he walking 'tick

translation.en: A boy and a boss can't court in the same house.
translation.creole: Boy an' bass can't cou'tin' a-wan house

translation.en: A boastful story doesn't hold water.
translation.creole: Briggah 'tory no lock a-gooby

translation.en: A boastful tongue is empty inside.
translation.creole: Briggah tongue hab empty inside

translation.en: A broom is not absent from anyone's house.
translation.creole: Broom na absen' a-nobody house

translation.en: The aboriginal Indian has time, he makes a wicker basket.
translation.creole: Buck gat time, he mek pegall

translation.en: The aboriginal Indian is enjoying himself, the aboriginal Indian's town is burning.
translation.creole: Buck a-plesha, Buck town a-bu'n

translation.en: What's happening, look out quickly before it passes.
translation.creole: Wha' a-pass, look out quick befo' he pass

translation.en: What comes from the devil's back goes under his belly.
translation.creole: Wha' come from de debil back go undah he belly

translation.en: What comes out of your stomach won't go into mine.
translation.creole: Wha' come out a-you belly no a-go in a-me own

translation.en: What comes out must go in.
translation.creole: Wha' come out sa go in

translation.en: What is the house in front of you, what is the bush for us.
translation.creole: Wha' da-house a-fo' you, wha' da-bush a-f' awe

translation.en: What's on the ground is for the dog, but not all dogs will pick it up.
translation.creole: Wha' deh a-groun' fo' daag, but no all daag a-pick am

translation.en: What's in the stick's head, is in the snake's head.
translation.creole: Wah' deh a stick head, deh a-snake head

translation.en: What's in your stomach doesn't need to come out of your mouth.
translation.creole: Wha' deh a-you belly na mek am pass t'rough you' mout'

translation.en: What's in the old goat must be in the kid.
translation.creole: Wha' deh in de ol' goat mus' be in de picknie

translation.en: What falls in the fire, you will find it in the ashes.
translation.creole: Wha' fall a-fiah you sa fin' am a-ashes

translation.en: What falls from the head goes to the shoulder.
translation.creole: Wha' fall from head go a-shouldah

translation.en: What was the fly doing before the cow got a sore eye?
translation.creole: Wha' fly bin a-do befo' cow get sore yeye?

translation.en: What can a fly do with a turtle's back?
translation.creole: Wha' fly can do wid tu'tle' back?

translation.en: What happens to the black fowl will happen to the white fowl.
translation.creole: Wha' happen to black fowl sa happen to white fowl

translation.en: What hurts the eye makes the nose run water.
translation.creole: Wha' hu't yeye mek nose run watah

translation.en: What was the Mahaica man doing before Munro's horse died of glanders?
translation.creole: Wha' Mahaica niggah bin a-do befo' Munro glandas haas dead?

translation.en: What motion quicksilver has at the bottom, it doesn't have at the top.
translation.creole: Wha' motion quicksilver got a-battam, he na gat a-sluice

translation.en: What's not good for breakfast is not good for dinner.
translation.creole: Wha' no good fo' breakfas' no good fo' dinnah

translation.en: What has passed, let it go; what is to come, sit down and wait for it.
translation.creole: Wha' pass chase am let 'e go, wha' a-come si down wait am

translation.en: What sense is in a snake's head, the same is in a stick's head.
translation.creole: Wha' sense deb a-snake head, de same deh a-bostick-head

translation.en: What does the term "tocle" have to do with a cow-fly?
translation.creole: Wha' some'ting tocle sa do wid cow-fly?

translation.en: What the eye doesn't see, the heart doesn't burn for.
translation.creole: Wha' yeye no see haat no bu'n

translation.en: What the ears don't hear, the heart doesn't burn over.
translation.creole: Wha' ears no heah haat no bu'n

translation.en: What your eyes don't see, your mouth doesn't water for.
translation.creole: Wha' you' eye no see you mout' no run watah

translation.en: What you gain in one area, you lose in another.
translation.creole: Wha' you gain in jigging you lose in shuffling

translation.en: What you put in the pickle never spoils.
translation.creole: Wha' you put in de pickle nebbah 'pile

translation.en: What's too heavy for your hand, roll it on the ground.
translation.creole: Wha' too heaby fo' you han' roll am a-groun'

translation.en: What you lost in the saucepan, you must find in the bottom of the coal pot.
translation.creole: Wha' you loss a-saucepan you mus' fin' a-bottom coal pot

translation.en: When an aboriginal Indian wants to harm you, he says "Fair play, no pilfering".
translation.creole: When Buck wan' a-damage you he say "Fair play no pra pra

translation.en: When a building catches fire, the master begs the laborer for help.
translation.creole: When buil'in' a-ketch fiah massa beg labrah

translation.en: When two bulls meet, they call each other "Brother".
translation.creole: When bull an' bull meet dey call matty "Bro

translation.en: When two bulls are in conversation, the steer has no business there.
translation.creole: When bull an' bull a-chat, capoon na gat business deh

translation.en: When cassava and okra meet in the pot, the pot must burn.
translation.creole: When cassada an' ochro meet a-pat, pat mus' bu'n

translation.en: When the cat's belly is full, it says "The rat stinks".
translation.creole: When cat belly full, he say "Ratta 'tink

translation.en: When a cat can't get milk, it remembers there are birds in the bush.
translation.creole: When cat na get milk, he 'membah bi'd a-bush

translation.en: When the carrion crow gets an itch in its eye, it thinks it's a governor.
translation.creole: When claninclo get yeye-tickle he t'ink hese'f gubnah

translation.en: When the carrion crow has eaten its fill, it flaps its wings at its neighbor.
translation.creole: When claninclo nyam belly-full, he shake 'e wing 'pon 'e matty

translation.en: When a chigger is in your foot, it's as tough as being pricked with a cattan.
translation.creole: When chiggah foot a rattan 'tuff am wid cattan

translation.en: When a coconut falls from the tree, it can't be reattached.
translation.creole: When coc'nut fall from tree he can't fasten back

translation.en: When a cockroach hosts a dance, he doesn't invite the chicken.
translation.creole: When cockroach gie dance, he no hax fowl

translation.en: When a poor man gets money, he shakes the governor's hand.
translation.creole: When cocoby man get money, 'e shake gubnah han'

translation.en: When a tough man meets another tough man, he says "There's no time."
translation.creole: When cuffman meet cuffman he say "Time no deh

translation.en: When a dog gets hit, it tucks its tail under its belly and runs away, yelping for sure, but watch out when it comes back.
translation.creole: When daag get lick he put 'e tail under he belly an' run an' halla fo' true, but look sharp when he come back

translation.en: When pork is delicious, a person keeps it in their mouth for a long time.
translation.creole: When flesin po'k sweet, man a-keep am lang a-he mout'

translation.en: When one bird meets another in bird country, one tells the other "Just like that!"
translation.creole: When fowl an' fowl meet a-fowl country, tara tell tara "So by

translation.en: When the rooster gets drunk, he forgets that the black-handled knife is in the kitchen.
translation.creole: When fowl-cock get grog, he fo'get say "black 'andle knife deh a-kitchen

translation.en: When chickens have teeth and dogs eat razors.
translation.creole: When fowl get teet' an' daag nyam razah

translation.en: When the ibis sees fish, it forgets that there's a gun.
translation.creole: When galin see fish, he fo'get say "Gun deh

translation.en: When a goat wants to roll, it rolls without the wind blowing it.
translation.creole: When goat down wan' roll he roll widout win' blow am

translation.en: When there's no horse, a donkey takes first place.
translation.creole: When haas na deh, jackass mek fus' place

translation.en: When he is calling God's name, that's when he is lying.
translation.creole: When he a-call Gad name, á de time he lie

translation.en: When he is here, he is here, when he is not here, he is not here.
translation.creole: When he deh he deh, when he na deh he na deh

translation.en: When the herring is fat and cooking, not everyone gets to smell it.
translation.creole: When herrin' fat a-bu'n, na all man a-smell am

translation.en: When a coolie (a person of Indian descent) is hungry, he is happy to eat pork.
translation.creole: When hungry ketch coolie, he glad fo' eat po'k

translation.en: When a donkey kicks a man, the man shouldn't bother to kick it back.
translation.creole: When jackass kick man, man mus'n't baddah kick am back

translation.en: When a little boy puts on a big man's trousers, he must accept what he gets.
translation.creole: When li'l boy put on big man trouses, wha' he get he mus' take

translation.en: When a small dog has a big liver, it will die before its time.
translation.creole: When li'l daag gat big libah, he go dead befo' 'e time

translation.en: When a little child wants to run, give him a long rope.
translation.creole: When li'l niggah wan' run, gie am lang rope

translation.en: When a man is going to eat at a woman's house, he must let the woman eat first.
translation.creole: When man a-go eat a-wan ooman 'ouse, he mus' leh a ooman eat fus'

translation.en: When a man is about to jump a fence, he must look carefully before he jumps.
translation.creole: When man a-go jump fence, he must look good befo' he jump

translation.en: When a man is writing, do not touch his pen.
translation.creole: When man a-write, no touch he pen

translation.en: When a man buys butter, his friend dips his finger deep.
translation.creole: When man buy buttah, he matty chook he fingah deep

translation.en: When a man is living well, he calls God "Congah".
translation.creole: When man get good libin' he call God "Congah

translation.en: When a man makes himself sugar, his friends will surely suck it.
translation.creole: When man mek hese'f sugah, 'e matty suck am fo' true

translation.en: When a man doesn't have a match, he uses a fire-stick to light the lamp.
translation.creole: When man na gat match he tek fiah-'tick fo' light lamp

translation.en: When a man sucks cane, he throws its peel on the ground.
translation.creole: When man suck cane, 'e mash 'e pilin' a-groun.'

translation.en: When a man wants to beat a dog, he finds a stick quickly.
translation.creole: When man wan' fo' beat daag, he 'fin' 'tick quick

translation.en: When my foot itches me, it's a sign that I'm going to walk.
translation.creole: When me foot itch me, a sign me go walk

translation.en: When my left hand itches, money is coming.
translation.creole: When me lef' han' 'cratch me, money a-come

translation.en: When my eyes are dancing, it's a sign I'm going to cry.
translation.creole: When me yeye a-dance, a sign me go cry

translation.en: When one tooth hurts you, all the rest are upset.
translation.creole: When one toot' hu't you, all de res' bex

translation.en: When the patwa (a type of fish) sees bait, it forgets that there's a hook at the bottom.
translation.creole: When patwa see bait, 'e fo'get say "'Ook de a-battam

translation.en: When a puppy gets plenty of milk, it turns up its nose at salt soup.
translation.creole: When puppy get plenty milk, he mek up he face 'pon sal' soup

translation.en: When it's drizzling, the devil and his wife are fighting for a ham bone.
translation.creole: When rain a-drizzle, debil an' he wife a-fight fo' ham bone

translation.en: When it's raining and the sun is shining, the devil is beating his wife.
translation.creole: When rain fall an' sun shining, debil licking he wife

translation.en: When a rat sees a cat, it never laughs.
translation.creole: When rat see cat, 'e nebbah laugh

translation.en: When the saucepan loses its cover, everyone peeps inside.
translation.creole: When saucepan loss he cobah, all man a-peep inside

translation.en: When a wound can't heal, one must sit down and bear it.
translation.creole: When sore can't get bettah, man gat fo' si' down bear am

translation.en: When the tiger gets old, the dog barks at it.
translation.creole: When ti'gah get ol', daag ba'k aftah am

translation.en: When the tiger is not there, the monkey gives the ball.
translation.creole: When tigal na deh, monkey gie ball

translation.en: When the tiger is sick, the deer lends him money.
translation.creole: When tigah sick, deer dun am fo' money

translation.en: When trouble comes, it doesn't blow its shell.
translation.creole: When trouble come, he no blow 'e shell

translation.en: When a white person gets into trouble, even a monkey's trousers will fit him.
translation.creole: When trouble ketch Bacra, monkey breeches fit am

translation.en: When trouble catches a man, he stands up and staggers; When trouble catches a woman, she sits down and considers.
translation.creole: When trouble ketch man, he 'tan' up an' 'taggah; When trouble ketch ooman, him si-down an' considah

translation.en: When two big bottles are on the table, the little one has no business there.
translation.creole: When two big bottle deh a-table, little wan no bu'iness

translation.en: When the barrel doesn't have a hoop, it must break down.
translation.creole: When tub na got hoople, he mus' bruck down

translation.en: When two dogs are fighting, the cat stands to one side.
translation.creole: When two daag get quarrel, Tom cat 'tan wan side

translation.en: When your brother is in trouble, don't laugh at him.
translation.creole: When you bruddah soak, don' laugh he

translation.en: When you're dead, you don't know, and when you know, you're already dead.
translation.creole: When you' dead you no sabby, an' when you sabby, you dead done

translation.en: When you get a donkey to ride, ride it for real.
translation.creole: When you get jackass fo' ride, ride am fo' true

translation.en: When you go into the bush, don't take the same road to come back.
translation.creole: When you go a-bush, no walk same road come back

translation.en: When you go to the countryside where they dance with one foot, you should also dance with one foot.
translation.creole: When you go a-country weh dem a-dance wid one foot, dance wid one foot too

translation.en: When you visit a friend's house, leave your appetite behind.
translation.creole: When you go a-frien' house, lef' you' 'tomach behin'

translation.en: When you have money, doors open; when you don't have, they shut.
translation.creole: When you gat money, doo' open; when you no gat, he shut

translation.en: When you have the devil to deal with, feed him with a long spoon.
translation.creole: When you hab de debil fo' deal wid, feed am wid long 'poon

translation.en: When your hand is yellow, dogs will make it so.
translation.creole: When you' han' yalla, daag mek so

translation.en: When you kill a bush cow, be careful how you carry it to the canoe.
translation.creole: When you kill comma, min' how you carry am a-canoe

translation.en: When you leave a wake, don't say "Good night".
translation.creole: When you lef' wake house, no say "Goo' night

translation.en: When you step on a dog, put on your shoes.
translation.creole: When you mash daag, put on you' shoes

translation.en: When your own louse bites you, it really bites you.
translation.creole: When you own louse bite you, he bite you fo' true

translation.en: ﻿My Hero Is You
translation.creole: Mi Staar Gyal a Yu

translation.en: How kids can fight COVID-19!
translation.creole: Hou piknii kyan fait KOVID-19!

translation.en: The making of “My Hero is You”
translation.creole: Hou “Mi Staar Gyal a Yu” kom

translation.en: This book was a project developed by the Inter-Agency Standing Committee Reference Group on Mental Health and Psychosocial Support in Emergency Settings (IASC MHPSS RG). The project was supported by global, regional and country based experts from Member Agencies of the IASC MHPSS RG, in addition to parents, caregivers, teachers and children in 104 countries. A global survey was distributed in Arabic, English, Italian, French and Spanish to assess children’s mental health and psychosocial needs during the COVID-19 outbreak. A framework of topics to be addressed through the story was developed using the survey results. The book was shared through storytelling to children in several countries affected by COVID-19. Feedback from children, parents and caregivers was then used to review and update the story.
translation.creole: Da buk a wahn wok wa di Inter-Agency Standing Committee Reference Group on Mental Health and Psychosocial Support in Emergency Settings (IASC MHPSS RG) du. Plenti a di biga hehd dem fram aal oova di worl, an aal oova di konchrii wa mek op di IASC MHPSS RG kom tugeda fu du da wok. Moda an faada, plos ada piipl wa doz tek keer a piknii, plos tiicha, an piknii from 104 konchrii doz help tu. Dem put tugeda wahn set a kweshtan in Arabik, Ingglish, Italiyan, French an Spanish fu fain out if dem piknii main doz wok gud an if eniiting rang wid dem, kaaz a di KOVID-19 siknis. Dem yuuz di ansa wa dem get from di kweshtan dem fu kom op wid wahn lis a ting fu taak bout in di stoorii. Dem bin sheer di stoorii in di buk tu piknii in nof difran konchrii wa ga KOVID-19 siknis. Bees pon wa di piknii dem, an dem moda an faada, an dem ada piipl wa doz luk aafta piknii se, dem go bak an fiks op di stoorii.

translation.en: Over 1,700 children, parents, caregivers and teachers from around the world took the time to share with us how they were coping with the COVID-19 pandemic. A big thank you to these children, their parents, caregivers and teachers for completing our surveys and influencing this story. This is a story developed for and by children around the world.
translation.creole: Moor dan 1,700 piknii, dem moda an faada, aal dem piipl wa doz luk aafta piknii, an tiicha fram aal oova di worl tek di taim fu tel awii hou dem a diil wid di KOVID-19 siknis. Nof tangks tu dem piknii, dem moda an faada, ada piipl wa doz luk aafta dem, an dem tiicha dem fu ansa aal awii kweshtan dem an help mek di stoorii kom. Dis a wahn stoorii wa aal dem piknii mek op fu dem matii aal oova di worl.

translation.en: This IASC MHPSS RG acknowledge Helen Patuck for writing the story script and illustrating this book.
translation.creole: Da IASC MHPSS RG tangk Helen Patuck fu rait di stoorii an fu jraa di picha dem wa in di buk.

translation.en: Introduction
translation.creole: Bout di buk

translation.en: “My Hero is You” is a book written for children around the world affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
translation.creole: “Mi Staar Gyal a Yu” a wahn buk wa rait fu piknii aal oova di worl wa KOVID-19 siknis a bada.

translation.en: “My Hero is You” should be read by a parent, caregiver or teacher alongside a child or a small group of children. It is not encouraged for children to read this book independently without the support of a parent, caregiver or teacher. The supplementary guide called “Actions for Heroes” (to be published later) offers support for addressing topics related to COVID-19, helping children manage feelings and emotions, as well as supplementary activities for children to do based on the book.
translation.creole: Moda ar faada, ar ada piipl wa luk aafta piknii, ar tiicha fu riid “Mi Staar Gyal a Yu” wid wahn piknii ar wahn lil gruup a piknii. Awii na reeli waahn piknii fu riid a buk bai deself widout dem moda ar faada, ar piipl wa a tek keer a dem, ar dem tiicha a help dem. Anada buk wa neem “Tingz wa Staar Gyal fu du” (wa go kom out leeta) go help awii fu fain a wee fu diil wid KOVID-19, an it kyan help piknii fu konchrool wa dem a tingk an wa dem a  fiil, plos am ga ada tingz fu di piknii dem du bees pon wa in di buk.

translation.creole: Chransileeshan

translation.en: The Reference Group itself will coordinate translation into Arabic, Chinese French, Russian, and Spanish. Contact the IASC Reference Group for Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS) (mhpss.refgroup@gmail.com) for coordination of translations in other languages. All completed translations will be posted on the IASC Reference Group website.
translation.creole: Di Reference Group self go put tugeda dem oon chransileeshan in Arabik, Chainiiz, French, Roshan, an Spanish. Lingk wid di IASC Reference Group for Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS) (mhpss.refgroup@gmail.com) fu put tugeda chransileeshan in ada langgwij. Aal chransileeshan wa don go get put op pon di IASC Reference Group websait.
